Name: Hxaro
Description:
System of mutual reciprocity partnerships

'Each family creates ties which distribute its risk over the population and thereby assure that losses will be covered in bad years.' (Wiessner (1982), p. 66)

'The hxaro relationship involves a balanced, delayed exchange of gifts, whose continuous flow gives both partners information about the underlying status of the relationship - one of a bond of a friendship accompanied by mutual reciprocity and access to resources. In addition, each partnership links a person to a broad network of hxaro paths' (p. 66)

Name: Headman
Description:
Headman. According to Lee, headmen become more prominent upon contact with British colonizers and black settlers. Headmen are often elders and have other personal qualities that distinguish them. But they have no formal authority. 

The figure of the headman changes dramatically when incorporated into the Botswana state
Institutional links: leader of the community, heads the kgotla

Name: Group
Description: Decisions are made by the group and by discussion. Women also participate, but their participation is not equal to that of men (Lee p. 44)

Name: Kgotla
Description:
Court

Led by the headman. introduced upon contact with the Batswana. enables dispute resolution beyond feuding. this is a late development, dating to the late 1940s

Name: Village Founder-Leader (dzoma)
Description:
Person with the highest authority in the village.
Responsible for:
-	Founding villages, initiating yearly household-based ancestor offerings, officiating at annual communal rites, adjudicating intravillage disputes, fining those who transgress Customs (e.g. adulterers) (Lewis 1968b; 1969-70:128-134) (Kammerer, p. 90-91)
-	The ceremonies led by the Village Founder-Leader primarily concern the welfare of the entire community. (Kammerer, p. 103)

"lead" rather than "rule":
-	A better translation for “dzo” is “to lead” (Kammerer, p. 93)
-	It is his duty to follow Customs; he cannot impose his individual will upon villagers in his care (Kammerer, p. 93)

Requirements:
-	Must uphold Customs. However, expert knowledge of oral tradition and ritual procedures is not a prerequisite for office. (Kammerer, p. 95)
-	Must be “pure” or “clean”: his wife cannot have been pregnant at the time of their marriage and together they cannot ever have produced twins or deformed children. (Kammerer, p. 94)
-	A man must give up his position if he is no longer “clean”. (Kammerer, p. 94)
-	Qualifications: he is calm, impartial, and sincere man willing to listen to others who are better versed in the intricacies of Customs. (Kammerer, p. 95)

Succession: 
-	The office is not necessarily inherited. (Kammerer, p. 94)
-	A son, usually the youngest who remains behind in his parents’ household after his older brothers have established independent households, often succeeds his deceased father. 
-	Such succession, must however, be ratified by the male elders. (Kammerer, p. 94)
-	Male heads of families planning to form a new community may jointly nominate one among themselves or recruit another respected “clean” man to select the site and serves as Village Founder-Leader. (Kammerer, p. 94)

Extra:
-	The Village Founder-Leader’s life thus differs little from that of his neighbours, even though he is respected by virtue of his office. (Kammerer, p. 95)
-	The first house built (usually near the centre of the settlement) must be his (Grunfeld 1982:54; Lewis 1969-70:125-128; Lewis and Lewis 1984: 218) (Kammerer, p. 90)
-	“If there is no Founder-Leader (dzoma), a village cannot be built” (Kammerer, p. 90)
Institutional links:
Council of Elders:
-	Although dzoma does arbitrate disputes and impose fines, he does not do so alone. (p. 93)
-	Rather he does so in consultation with other male elders; his decision legitimises the consensus reached (p. 93)

Name: Assistant Founder-Leaders (dzoza)
Description:
There were 4 types of Assistant Founder-Leaders:
-	1) The son of the Village Founder Leader
-	2) Selected by male elders in communities in which he had previously lived. His father had been an Assistant Village Founder-Leader.
-	3) Selected by male elders in communities in which he had previously lived. His father had not been an Assistant Village Founder-Leader.
-	4) Chosen by the community’s male elders. This man’s paternal grandfather had served as a Village Founder-Leader, but his father had not.

Name: Strongman (xaqma)
Description:
Officials responsible for village defence.
-	“Fighters” (p. 97 (Alting 1983:268), 98)
-	Role: Village defence (p. 97 (Alting 1983:268), 98)

Name: Blacksmith
Description:
Blacksmith (baji in everyday speech; ciqma in the archaic oral tradition)
-	Position is restricted to men (p. 98)
-	Not automatically hereditary. Nonetheless, the craft is often taught by an older to a younger relative. (p. 98)
-	It is not necessary for a Blacksmith to be “clean” (p. 99)
-	Within a community there may be more than one Blacksmith. (p. 99)

Name: Reciter (p'ima)
Description:
A religious officer trained in ritual texts of the oral tradition and responsible for ceremonies that concern the welfare of an individual or a patrilineal kin unit.
Some of his roles:
-	The elaborate funeral ceremony for an adult in which the Reciter’s chanting guides the deceased to the above of the ancestors (Hanks 1974; Hanson 1983) (p. 103)
-	Leads the various purification rites following a “bad death” (p. 103)
-	Enact ceremonies to re-establish order after the birth of twins or a malformed child. (p. 103)
-	Nevertheless, neither birth nor marriage rituals are his province. (p. 104)

-	Recitation of the ritual texts of the oral tradition is the essence of the office. (p. 100)
-	To become a Reciter a man must study with one or more Reciters. (p. 100)
-	During his apprenticeship he is known as p’iza “Apprentice Reciter”. (p. 100-101)
-	This position is achieved rather than inherited. (p. 101)
-	Requisitions: “clean” man who has the intelligence and perseverance required to memorise the vast corpus of ritual chants (p. 101)
-	He must provide his mentor with liquor and stipulated gifts, including a set of new clothes. (p. 101)
-	Although the office is not inherited, many men are taught by a patrilineal relative. In such cases the customary payment from a student to his teacher is not required. (p. 101)
-	Even a young Reciter spends few days, if any, working in his family’s fields. (p. 101)
-	Ceremonies led by the Reciter primarily concern the welfare of an individual or a patrilineal kin unit. 9p. 103)
-	The Reciter, unlike the Village Founder-Leader, has no official role in rituals of the annual cycle. (p. 103)
-	Although villagers prefer to have at least one Reciter among them, a community need not have a resident Reciter. (p. 103)
Institutional links: Division of labour: whilst the Village Founder-Leader is concerned with rituals of the annual cycle, Reciter leads ceremonies that primarily concern the welfare of an individual or a patrilineal kin unit.

Name: Village Headman (phuujajbaan)
Description:
A representative of the Akha people in Thailand's National government
-	His job is to act as liaison between government officials and villagers (p. 110)
-	Functionary in the national government system (p. 109)
-	Does not have to be “clean” (p. 110)
-	Receives a small monthly stipend from the District Office (amphur) for his services (p. 110)
-	He is obligated to attend regularly scheduled meetings at the District Office (p. 110)
-	Is the person contacted by various officials (e.g. field representatives of the Hill Tribe Welfare Division of the Department of Public Welfare, Ministry of the Interior (p. 110)
-	Maximum of 5 cycles. (p. 110)
-	Permitted to vote: those who have both a national identity card and a house registration card issued by the District Office (p. 110)
Institutional links: The representative in the National government

Name: White-Skirted Woman
Description:
A female official with ritual responsibilities that may partake in decision-making indirectly from behind the scenes.
-	Through her ritual responsibilities links annual ancestor offerings and yearly rice rituals. (p. 116)
-	Although she has no official say in village decision-making, her position is respected, and she may exert substantial influence behind the scenes, especially if she has a strong personality and has reached venerable age (p. 117)

Name: Council of Elders
Description:
A council with the highest power in the village.
-	Some ethnographic accounts report that village disputes are settled by a “council of elders” (for example, Lewis and Lewis 1984:227).
-	Kammerer prefers to avoid this phrase because it conveys what she considers to be a false impression of formality, rigidity, and corporateness. (Kammerer, p. 118)
-	Every male head of patrilineal family should attend meetings called by the Village Founder-Leader. (Kammerer, p. 118)
-	Full attendance may not be realised, and an old man may well send a son in his stead.
-	Issues are discussed until a consensus is reached, and his consensus is validated by the Village Founder-Leader (Kammerer, p. 118-p. 119) 
-	Elders sit at the esteemed downslope tables at ceremonial meals. (Kammerer, p. 119)
-	Women and men are invited independently to these meals (p. 119)
-	A man may have sat at a men’s downslope tables for years before his wife is asked to sit at a women’s downslope table for the first time. (Kammerer, p. 119).
-	(abo and ap’i).
Institutional links: Council of Elders discuss issues, and their consensus is validated by the Village Founder-Leader

Name: Sama
Description:
A gifted person shosen by spirits that identifies cures for illnesses in her dreams.
-	Chosen by spirits (p. 118)
-	Being “not clean” does not prevent spirits from selecting an individual as a sama (p. 118)
-	The sama’s insight into curing is obtained in dreams rather than during travels in trance. (p. 118)
-	Curers of both sorts are usually adept at setting broken bones and knowledgeable about medical plants. (p. 118)

Name: Shaman
Description:
A gifted person chosen by spirits that identifies the cause of the illness through entering trance to the world of the ancestors.
-       Open to both men and women (Kammerer, p. 117)
-	Enter trance to the world of the ancestors to seek aid in finding lost souls of the sick or in identifying the agents causing illness and the type of rituals needed to appease them. (p. 117)
-	The Shaman’s job thus overlaps with that of the Reciter. (p. 117)
-	Many communities do not have a resident Shaman (p. 118)
-	Shaman is chosen by spirits. (p. 118)
-	Potentially not necessary to be “clean” (p. 118)

Name: Prefetturii/ Conti/ Dogi
Description:
Annual magistracy (board), each figure operates in a different period but covering roughly the same tasks. Elected by the popular assembly. Often filled by heredity.

Camera, M. p. 70 ("Amalfi (…) veniva governata da un Pretore, o Epata, come i Greci lo chiamavano ed era immediatamente dipendente e sommessa al Duca, Console, o Maestro de Soldati di Napoli") | Camera, M. p. 89 ("eligendosi dapprima i Prefetti annuali, poi i Conti e poscia i Dogi, i quali non erano principi assoluti o ereditari, ma bensì elettivi della repubblica, e che governando con pieno potere si sceglievano dal corpo della nobiltà") | Camera, M. p. 111 ("Poco soddisfatti gli Amalfitani del sistema di governo de loro Prefetti e Conti, e quasi annojati per lo spazio di 42 anni da quella magistratura, si dettero premura d'innalzarla a più orrevole grado con l'eligervi di Dogi") | Camera, M. p 111, nota 1 ("Doge, così detto per distinzione de duchi feudatari. Gli amalfitani non soggetti a' principi Longobardi, non solo non conobbero i feudi al pari de' Greci a cui ubbidivano; ma anche altre leggi non regnarono presso loro, salvo che quelle dominanti fra greci al pari delle altre città non soggette a' Longobardi")

Camera, M. p 89 ("Noi però colla scorta di tutte le nostre cronache possiamo francamente affermare che l'elezione de' nostri Dogi dipendeva dall'assoluto consenso del popolo e de' nobili tal quale eseguisvasi in Venezia; e tal volta si succedevano i parenti più prossimi")

Name: Sedile di congrega
Description:
Elite council

Camera, M. p. 238 ("Un sedile di congrega altra volta richiamava tutti i patrizi Amalfitani a discutere e pronunziare su propri e particolari, come publici interessi; e le leggi e consuetudini patrie venivano eseguite con rigorosa osservanza")

Name: Tavole Amalfitane
Description:
Leggi e regolamenti nautici

Camera, M. p. 208 ("Obbligaronli a pubblicare delle proprie leggi, e regolamenti nautici, che Tavole Amalfitane appellavansi")

Name: Consudetudini
Description:
Leggi scritte della repubblica di Amalfi

Camera, M. p. 211 ("Oltre le prenominate Tavole Amalfitane, sappiamo esservi state ancora altre proprie e particolari leggi che Amalfitane Consuetudini chiamavansi. Desse erano in prima ripartite in 26 rubriche")

Name: Comizi
Description:
Popular assembly

M. p 89 ("Noi però colla scorta di tutte le nostre cronache possiamo francamente affermare che l'elezione de' nostri Dogi dipendeva dall'assoluto consenso del popolo e de' nobili tal quale eseguisvasi in Venezia; e tal volta si succedevano i parenti più prossimi")

Camera, M. p. 238 ("Ne comizi o pubbliche adunanze il popolo non era affatto escluso dal suo parere")

Name: Rajan
Description:
King.

It could be appointed for life by heads of families in monarchical states. or it could be among other rajanah ruling alongside an assembly
Institutional links: it depends on whether the community is type 1-4

Name: Sabhā
Description: Council of elders or of the important men of the tribe, selected because of their distinction in warfare, eloquence, knowledge or property Sharma p. 35
Institutional links: it depends on whether the community is type 1-4

Name: Samiti
Description: Assembly. probably consisted of the heads of families of the community (p, 42) who in turn represented the entire population
Institutional links: it depends on whether the community is type 1-4

Name: King
Description: King of England

Name: witan
Description: King's council. the membership is debated but it was possibly a large elite gathering (close to an elite assembly than to a small council). met regularly. Decided diplomatic matters, proposed royal charters and discussed taxation
Metanotes: Check out Levi Roach for further info on institutional links

Name: shire reeve
Description: sheriff, presiding over a shire, tasked with the administration of justice and raising revenue.

Name: shire court
Description: Court at the level of the shire

Name: gemot
Description: Court of 12, operating at the smaller administrative unit of the hundred. may have met regularly

Name: wapentake
Description: Administrative division corresponding to the hundred. Possibly also a court presided by a 'hundredman."

Name: King
Description:
King, chief executive of the community

Assur's king held two titles: Isshiak Assur, or “Divine Assur’s steward” (the emphasis is on “the divinely sanctioned role as head of the community and as chief priest”) and Waklum, or “Leader” (the emphasis on its role as the implementer of judicial decisions taken by the city-assembly)

Name: Alum
Description:
City assembly, central political and judicial institution of the community, it was composed by the elders and notables of Assur. It could be divided and set into special committees to look into especially complex cases, including audits and financial transactions. judicial functions.

"The assembly is to be divided into voting blocks in order to reach a majority decision. All of these activities were supervised by the scribe or secretary of the Port, clearly a salaried official." p 84
Institutional links: Regulated by the rules of the constitution. Made up of the elders

Name: Limmum
Description: Annual office whose holder gave his name to the year in the same way as the archons or the consuls, i.e. a year-eponymy. He functioned as the head of the main administrative office, City-Hall.
Institutional links: Presumably chosen by the elders of the city-assembly. Head of City Hall.

Name: City hall
Description: Bureaucracy in charge of taxation and administration
Institutional links: Manages the city. The Limmum is the head of city-hall.

Name: Scribe
Description:
Salaried official supervising assembly 

All of these activities were supervised by the scribe or secretary of the Port, clearly a salaried official." p 8

Name: Tlatoani
Description: King, chosen among the male members of the royal dynasty by a council of high nobles. heredity and (military) meritocracy determine selection. succession is usually father to son or brother to brother

Name: Council of high nobles
Description: Able to choose the king from male members of the royal dynasty. They organised various aspects of the city-state government. They were judges, tribute collectors, high-ranking military officials and general royal advisors.

Name: Governor
Description: Governor of the city-state
Institutional links: Appointed and controlled by the central administration.

Name: Council of Elders
Description: Civic institution either coextensive with or part of the city assembly. The specific functions are not clear in the extant evidence.
Institutional links: Coextensive with or part of the city assembly

Name: The citizens/The Assembly of the city
Description:
A civic institution that holds authority on behalf of the
community and bears its name (Barjamovic 2004, p. 56). Interchangeably used with "the assembly". Functions may have included choosing governors, waging war, directing foreign policy, exercising legal functions, control funds for public works and cultic functions.

Name: Rab kohanim
Description:
Chief priest
'besides his important religious role, also exercised great influence over the workings of the State and economic life' (p. 41)

Name: Council of Elders
Description: Similar to the Roman Senate or the Greek gerousia
Institutional links: Advised the king but could also act on their own behalf

Name: Tribunal of 104
Description: Tribunal of judges

Name: Suffetes
Description:
Two annually elected officials

Similar to Roman consuls

Name: Ham
Description:
Parliamentary assembly.

Convened by the suffetes, the assembly had several functions  including the election of generals (Lancel p. 119)

Name: Senatus
Description: Controlling body among the Aedui. No information available about membership or size.

Name: Elected magistrates
Description:
Magistrates.

Elected but unclear by whom.

Name: Assemblies
Description: Annual auction of the right to collect tolls from merchants. Probably controlled by local elites. rather than a d-m institution in its own right, the assembly was probably a way to convey some form of military support.

Name: Big man
Description: Leader of each village, a primus inter pares

Name: Council
Description: Made up of representatives of the founding matrilineages of the vicinage - these are people that occupy the highest rank of the ngongo munene.
Institutional links: composed of the highest rank of the ngongo munene

Name: ngongo munene
Description:
A sodality that includes several ranks
-	The lower ranks are open to all men
-	The higher are occupied by heredity, reputation, and the paying of large fees
Institutional links: highest ranks make up the council

Name: Council of Five Hundred (Boule)
CGI: Council (central) ,Agenda setting,Representation,Voting,Age boundaries,Deliberation,Temporary position of power/Term Limits,Frequent and/or regular meetings,Lottery/Random Selection,Remunerated position,Turnover/rotation,Scrutiny of officials
Description: 'conducted Athens’ day-­ to-­ day public affairs and set the agenda for the legislative citizen assembly,' (Ober, Josiah (2015), p. 164)
Institutional links:
Sets agenda for the citizen assembly (ekklesia)

Does not make independent decisions without the ekklesia

Name: Areopagus
Description: A special court throughout the period of the democracy. made up of ex-archons.

Name: Ekklesia
CGI: Assembly (central),Majority voting,Consensus,Age boundaries,Frequent and/or regular meetings,Suspension/Expulsion/Ostracism/Proscription,Vote by show of hands
Description: The people's assembly, in charge of all decision making. in the 5th century, made decisions about ostracism
Institutional links: Its agenda is set by the Council of Five Hundred

Name: People's courts
CGI: Tribunal/Court ,Age boundaries,Frequent and/or regular meetings,Litigation,Lottery/Random Selection,Majority voting,Oath,Public meetings,Temporary position of power/Term Limits,Judicial review,Remunerated position,Secret ballot
Description: Popular tribunals administering justice
Institutional links: Independent from other institutions except for judicial review procedure

Name: Magistrates
CGI: Magistrate/official,Board/Committee,Age boundaries,Turnover/rotation,Temporary position of power/Term Limits,Election,Lottery/Random Selection,Screening process,Scrutiny of officials
Description: Magistrates of the city, duties range from financial to military to administrative. Some are selected by lot, some are elected. we have evidence for at least 71 boards (Hansen, ADAD, 239). were probably paid in the 5th century but pay was discontinued in the 4th (ibid. 240-1)
Institutional links: implement decisions of the other bodies

Name: Rentmeister
Description: Chief financial official

Name: City council
Description: 'a small body of fifteen members that was renewed each year and for which the fifteen new members of the incoming council were chosen by the outgoing council' (p. 171)

Name: Rentkammern
Description: Annuity chambers (treasuries)

Name: Richerzeche
Description: 'a social club that included the city’s great merchants and property owners.' (Stasavage, States of Credit, p. 171, EPUB)

Name: Verbundbrief
Description: Constitution 'which was designed to ensure broader representation in Cologne’s governance' (p. 171)

Name: Gaffel
Description:
'22 individual corporations' on which the political system was based on after 1396 when the Richerzeche was abolished. 

the head of each Gaffel was not chosen in an open election by all members—they were instead selected by a special committee of more prominent members'
Institutional links: elects 36 of the 49 seats in the council

Name: States-General
Description: an assembly comprising representatives of each of the seven provinces (each has one vote aiming at unanimity in theory but often using majority [cf. Israel p. 276], rotating presidency with one province chairing meetings for one week at a time)
Institutional links: Top federal institution of the republic

Name: Provincial assembly
Description: Provincial assembly, representing the towns (but only some could vote), usually assisted by a standing committee, setting the agenda

Name: Vroedschap
Description:
Permanent council in the towns of the west, constituting the core of local government. The council was cooptive and its members had an appointment for life. Major policy decisions were discussed, and it was convened regularly. 
”From the ranks of the councillors the aldermen and mayors were recruited. The seven, nine, or eleven aldermen were the local court of justice. The majors, two or four of whom were always serving simultaneously, were the executive. Together, the aldermen and mayors constituted the magistracy, that acted as the legislative authority, in its own right or in conjunction with the council.”
Institutional links: Top governance institution in towns in the West

Name: Magistracies
Description:
Composed of aldermen and mayors. 

Selection differs in the east and west:
- west: Magistrates are recruited from the councillors, appointment is temporary and limited to 2/3 years at a stretch. usually magistrates are reelected and in the meantime they go back to the council

- east: magistrates who lost their seat were politically side-tracked. Many magistrates were elected through a procedure that involved the local community.
Institutional links: top governance institution in towns in the East

Name: Stadholder
Description: Entitled to appoint aldermen, and even the mayors. In this process, towns were entitled to propose candidates on a so-called double list, that restricted the choice for the stadholder and allowed the towns to manipulate the process. In practice, the stadholder picked one or two local confidants, who would make sure that the right people were on the list.
Institutional links: Appointing aldermen and mayors (everywhere in Netherlands).

Name: Shogun
Description: Considered 'hegemons' since they could issue ordinances commanding the daimyo (p.434). They had the power to suppress rebels and move the domains of daimyos from one part of the country to another. (p.433). Collected funds from daimyos, but not involved in taxation.
Institutional links: Appointed by the Emperor. Like the daimyo, the shogun were also given control of provinces, but did not play an active role in their administration and often entrusted this to their favoured daimyos.

Name: Daimyo
Description: Baron like domain administrators. They had a high degree of autonomy over their domain's internal affairs, like structuring landownership policies. (p.434) They were responsible for tax collection and assessed taxes on a village as a corporate entity, but not on individual farm households (p.435)
Institutional links: Since they levied taxes on villages as a whole, the village council could organise corporate landholding policies such that the share of the land owned by a citizen was proportional to the level of tax they paid.

Name: Village Council
Description: Domain administrative officials/members of the council for a village were chosen by its residents of the village from a list of candidates initially selected by the daimyo. However, posts like those of the village headman were often inherited through multiple generations of the same family (p.435), though this was not necessarily the case.
Institutional links: It was the council that led and organised the corporate landholding practises, but this included all the members of the village, The members of the council did not have any privileges in terms of getting better land allocations

Name: Samurai
Description: Some samurai were in charge of county administration and performed functions like maintaining public peace, collecting taxes. They also coordinated activities that required the cooperation of multiple villages, like riparian works and allocation of irrigation water. (p.435)
Institutional links: They were prevented from having links with the village administration - 'as a rule, samurai were prohibited from residing in villages or owning land.' (p.435)

Name: Emperor
Description: Considered to have a divine right to rule, but lacked little actual power

Name: Magistrates of the res publica
Description:
Board of two magistrates. 

This institution is at the head of each Etruscan city state after the 4th century. they seem to have held both military and judicial powers (p. 201)

Name: Maru
Description: Board of magistrates charged with public affairs (probably similar to the roman aediles). the office seems to have implied both civic duty and religious charges.

Name: Council of Rectors
Description: Second element of government in Genoa after 1194

Name: Podesta
Description:
Chief Executive

"In the 12th ce., a non-Genoese podesta was hired for a year to serve as a 'military leader, judge, and administrator and who was supported by the soldiers and judges he brought with him...Moreover, because the podesta was to receive a high wage at the end of his successful term, his threat was credible."

In the 13th century, the podesta becomes a widespread institution among the italian city-states (source: Epstein's chopter on the italian city states in Hansen's collection of 30 city states, p. 284)
Institutional links:
Supported by judges and soldiers

'The selection of an incoming podest`a was made by a committee of representatives from the city’s various neighborhoods' (p. 643)

Name: Doge
Description: Chief executive, elected

Name: Council
CGI: Council (central) ,Temporary position of power/Term Limits,Frequent and/or regular meetings
Description: Council of eight magistrates who served for terms of four months. These magistrates met almost daily and made all important decisions, in addition to nominating key administrative officials.

Name: Protectors of San Giorgio
Description: Members of the casa di San Giorgio, a compera (financial institution that involved a loan by private individuals to the state in exchange for the right to future revenues from a specific tax). Chosen by cooptation

Name: Magnum Concilium
Description: Assembly. Included the magistrates in addition to between 300 and 400 citizens. This was apparently not a regular institution, nor did it have regular procedures determining who would participate in its deliberations.
Institutional links: Includes the members of the Council

Name: Council of State
Description: Council of senior titled offices. These Included: Kaura (senior military commander, equivalent to the king’s prime minister), and Galadima (king’s deputy in relations with the noble lineages).

Name: Sarki
Description: King

Name: Aristocratic Offices
Description:
Other titled offices not part of the council. Occupied by men and women. Heredity and patronage.

Yerima (crown prince, not primogeniture based, but filled on the basis of ruler’s choice ratified by the members of the state council), Magajiya (queen’s mother, never the biological mother of the king, but senior member of the dynastic lineages), Limamin Juma’a (Islamic officer), Alkali (chief judge, pledging his loyalty to the sharia), Dan Sanwai (chief among ruler’s scribes)
Institutional links: depend on the king through allegiance and loyalty, as well as heredity

Name: Commoners' Offices
Description: Administrative functions. positions bought through the use of cowrie shells
Institutional links: depend on the king through patronage

Name: Slave offices
Description: Also involved in admin functions, as well as city defense
Institutional links: depend on the king through patronage

Name: Village chief
Description:
Despite having little real power apart from dispute resolution, chiefs were generally admired and considered learned, especially since they could speak several languages/dialects. After the death of a chief, a new one was chosen after informal deliberation and discussion amongst villagers. 

Chiefs often initiated the migration of a village and made a “political judgement about how much distance a community should put between itself and the state.” (pg. 317) because shifting cultivation meant that they were less likely to be state subjects. The village respected the chief's decision not because they were coerced into doing so but because they had a "genuine admiration" for his judgement.
Institutional links: Head of the village. His authority rests on capacities and merit

Name: Village shaman
Description:
“a prominent woman or man, often a shaman, would have a dream telling her to move to a new place” which led to the formation of daughter villages, frequently led by the dreamer (Scott, pg. 490)
Shamans would also interpret the dreams of other people since they were believed to have a connection to the spiritual world and it was frequently upon their advice that dreamers decided to form new villages.
Institutional links: Another figure of authority in the village

Name: Village gatherings
Description:
These are not formal assemblies but gatherings of the village to make important decisions, including migrating.

Before moving to a new village, the male heads of all the families in the village assembled at the dwelling of the headman or the dreamer. The decision to migrate with the village (at the behest of the village chief) or break away from the village (following the shaman/prominent person who had a dream/supernatural indication) depended on the personal respect and trust a family had in the figure of authority suggesting it. In these informal assemblies, each family declared its position. Those families who would migrate then stayed on to discuss the logistics of the move.
Institutional links: Gatherings at the house of the chief of shaman

Name: Captain
Description:
Village chief. 

"These Captains do not govern their subjects by means of command and absolute power; they have no force at hand to compel them to their duty. Their government is only civil; they represent only what is to be done for the good of the village" Jesuit relations p. 230

Name: Village council
Description:
The village council. 

'responsible for organizing the provision of public goods, such as the maintenance of the protective palisade for the inhabitants. It also organized redistribution of food in time of need and adjudicated legal disputes between members of different clans.' (Stasavage, p. 39)
Institutional links: Below the tribal and confederacy councils

Name: Tribal chief
Description: 'The tribal chief, though nominally in charge, had little coercive power and no real subordinates to use for this purpose, and individual clan chiefs retained a high degree of independence.' (Stasavage, p. 39)
Institutional links: Highly independent position. No real subordinates

Name: Tribe council
Description: Composed of the tribal chief and clan chiefs

Name: Confederacy council
Description:
'central authority was weak, and consensual decision making was the rule. Each tribe had the right to abide or not abide by a confederacy decision' (Stasavage, p. 39)

'those at the center had no independent means of coercion at their disposal' (p. 39)

take place on a need basis

Name: Gobi
Description:
Chieftain, (pl. Gobar) presides over the Thing in a panel of 3 and with 36 judges; also select judges.

Each local Thing was presided over by 3 chieftains (gobi, pl. gobar) and the panel of 36 judges selected by the gobar. (p.17)
Chieftains (gobi, pl. gobar): hallowed the assembly grounds and selected the judges who heard the cases tried at Things. (p.17)
The law required a person with property sufficient to qualify as a householder (bondi, pI. brendr) to attach himself to a chieftain for purposes of Thing attendance (p.22)
A bondi could transfer his allegiance from one chieftain to another simply by making an announcement of his intention at the Thing, and a chieftain could likewise terminate the bond. (p.23)

Name: Thing
Description:
Local Assembly, meets every spring, handles lawsuits and administration

Met every spring at varjJing, "springThing", at which lawsuits were heard and administration matters were handled. (p.17)

Name: Allthing
Description:
Central Assembly, meets annually for 2 weeks, open to all free men

Met annually for 2 weeks at midsummer at Thingvellir in the southwest of the country 

Each of the 36 chieftains holding what was designated an “ancient and full" chieftaincy was to name one judge to the panel. (p.17)

Name: Quarter court
Description:
Court of first instance for litigants belonging to different local Things. One per quarter. 

The 4 Quarter Courts met together at the Allthing. (p.17)
Provided the forum for those cases in which no judgment could be reached at the local Thing. (p.17) They served as courts of first instance for cases between litigants who were attached to different local Things. The appropriate venue in such cases was the defendant's Quarter court. (p.17)
Presided over by the panel of 36 judges selected by the gobar (chieftains) (p.17)
Concurrence of at least 31 judges out of a panel of 36 judges. (p.18)

Name: Fifth Court
Description:
Court of appeal for cases ending in a divided judgment in the Quarter courts.

Had original jurisdiction for cases involving harboring of outlaws, runaway slaves and churchpriests, as well as perjury and offers of bribes that occurred at the Allthing. (p.18)
Established: c. 1005 (p.17)
Judgment could be had by simple majority. (p.18) 
Panel of 48 judges, one chosen by each chieftain whether he held an “ancient and full" chieftaincy or a "new" chieftaincy established at the time of the division into quarters. (p.18)
“New” chieftains: 3 per South, East and West Quarter that were created to equalize the representation of these Quarters with the North Quarter (whose people had insisted on having four local Things and hence three more chieftains than the other Quarters). (p.18)
Judgment was still to be given by 36 judges, it being the responsibility of the litigants to dismiss 12 judges, 6 by each party, prior to judgment. (p.18)

Name: Logretta
Description:
Legislative authority within the Allthing

Consisted of 48 chieftains, the Lawspeaker, and (eventually) two bishops. (p.18)
Each chieftain was to appoint 2 Thingmen as advisors to sit with him in the court. (p.18)
The Logretta made and altered law and decided what the law was if there was disagreement about a rule, granted exemptions from the effects of certain laws, most notably the ecclesiastical prohibitions on marriage within certain degrees of kinship, and it elected the Lawspeaker. (p.18)

Name: Lawspeaker
Description:
part of the Logretta, alongside 48 chieftains and 2 bishops, elected for 3 years

Lawspeaker was elected for 3-year term. (p.18)
Lawspeaker: it was his responsibility to tell anyone who asked him what the law was. He was also obliged to recite the law in such a fashion that all the sections of the law were rehearsed by every third Allthing and the procedure section was repeated each year. (p.18)
Lawspeaker: law obliged him “to recite all the sections so extensively that no one knows them much more extensively. And if his knowledge does not stretch so far, then before reciting each section he is to arrange a meeting a day before with five or more legal experts, those from whom he can learn the most; and any man who intrudes on their talk without permission is fined three marks, and that case lies with the Lawspeaker.”  (Grtigtis Ia 209)” (p18-19)

Lawspeaker: the only paid officeholder in the system of governance (240 ells of vadmal annually). This was financed from payments made to the Logretta to purchase permission to marry within the prohibited degrees. He was also to receive one-half of the three-mark fines adjudged at the Alithing and in those local Things in which he happened to participate. (p.19)

Name: Leid
Description:
leid, pI. leidar, or haustping: Fall Things

Were held locally two weeks after the Allthing. (p19)
Provided a forum for announcing matters concluded at the Allthing and for reciting the calendar for the coming year. (p.19)

Name: Hreppadomar and Fedansdomr
Description:
Ad hoc courts formed pursuant to various procedures (e.g. courts called to partition meadows and jointly owned pasture 
(Grtigtis Ib 84-86, 11455-60; Ib 115-17, II 488-94)). (p.19)

Hreppadomar: courts called an arrowshot from the home of a defendant who had shirked his responsibilities for supporting dependent kin or the district poor 
(Grtigtis Ib 174-76, II 252-54) (p.19)

Fedansdomr: a court held to confiscate and settle an outlaw's estate.
(p.19)

Name: Hreppr
Description:
local administrative unit independent of the chieftain-Thing structures 

Function of arranging for the maintenance of the poor who fell between the cracks of the kin and household networks of support. (p.19) (See ch. 5)
Each unit was to have at least 20 households (smaller units could be established if the Logretta gave permission). (p.19)
Meetings: 3 times a year (additional meetings as needed). (p.19)
Hreppr: collected and distributed those tithes and mandatory contributions designated for the poor.
The poor were assigned to various households for differing lengths of time in proportion to the wealth of the household. (p.19)

Hreppr: administered an insurance system. (p.19)
Insurance system: A member who lost more than 1/4 of his herds to disease was entitled to recover 1/2 his loss. (p.19)
Fire Insurance: half the value of the loss for the 3 rooms of the farmhouse (the living room, the kitchen, and pantry). If a person had both a kitchen and a hall he had to declare in the spring hreppr-meeting which one he intended to have covered. No one was allowed to draw on the fund more than three times. (p.19)
Insurance: funded by by a maximum assessment of one six-ell ounce per 120 ounces of a member's total wealth (ie., 0.83 percent). If the fund was inadequate to cover losses, recoveries were reduced pro rata ( Gragas II 260-61). (p.20)

Name: Omu
Description:
Mother. Head of women. She and her cabinet represent women in deliberations and gatherings. When arriving at decisions, the onye oga sounds the ekwe to gather an assembly. In lesser decisions, word of mouth between the women suffices

	‘The omu, in her capacity as the head of the female side of the community, with her cabinet determined the rules and regulations under which the market – the domain of women – was to function. This included fixing prices for goods sold in the market and setting market prohibitions. The omu and her councillors presided over each market and acted as a court in judging cases and disciplining (largely through fines) any woman who broke the laws of the market.’ (49)
	‘The omu handled cases involving women that were brought to her from throughout the town. Men who had complaints against their wives that were beyond the competence of the family circle to deal with came to the omu to seek advice or redress. The omu gave advice to wives who sought it, and where she felt that she could not handle the situation herself, she and her cabinet sought the cooperation of the obi in council. Such cooperation in cases involving both sexes was the rule rather than the exception, especially in matters involving a man and his wife. Among the Igbo, arriving at a consensus on any major issue was vital. It was not enough for justice to be done; that such justice was done ought to be transparently clear to anybody.’ (50)
	‘The omu had direct responsibility for the institution of title-taking among women. Thus, if the omu had not acquired all the women’s titles of the community at the time of her nomination by the town oracle, her relatives rallied to help her secure them, since she could only encourage and perpetuate an institution of which she was fully a part.’ (50-51)
	‘The duty of the omu was to represent all the women of her community, and consequently she had to be very responsive to her constituency. Though the women of the community did not form a corporate body, the omu sought their cooperation in and approval of any major decisions through the institution called the ikporo ani.’ (51)
Institutional links: Stands next to the Obi,  summons the Ikporo Ani

Name: Obi
Description: Head of men. He and his cabinet represent men in deliberations and gatherings

Name: Ikporo Ani
Description:
A representative body of women chosen from each section or quarter of the village or town

	‘The ikporo ani was a representative body of women chosen from each section or quarter of the village or town. Sometimes representation was on the basis of lineage, but selection was always based on achievement: the representatives were not necessarily titled women, but were those who had previously demonstrated qualities of logic and ability to “talk well”; as such they had come to enjoy the confidence of their areas or lineages and were regarded as “leaders of opinion.” The women of the ikporo ani would meet at the summons of the omu and her councillors. They would report back to the other women, and again to the omu, until consensus was reached on any major issue. In this manner the entire ikporo ani felt part of the deliberations and bound by the final decisions.’ (51)
Institutional links: Meets at the summons of the omu and her councillors

Name: Onotu
Description: The obi’s council of dignitaries which aids him and acts as a restraining force against his arbitrary use of power. ‘This council usually contained twelve elders who had taken the full titles of the community.’ (48))

Name: Ilogo
Description:
The omu’s council ‘made up of councillors with titular ranks and duties corresponding on a one-to-one basis to those of the obi’s councillors. The omu’s councillors were generally women who had taken the full women’s titles of the community and women whose husbands had taken the full men’s titles.’ (48))

	‘The ilogo could challenge male authority in the community if necessary, for Igbo oral tradition tells of an omu who led a boycott by all the women of her community in which the women refused to cook for their husbands. Under the pressure of having to prepare their own meals, the men capitulated to the women’s demands.’ (48)
‘The male and female cabinets, despite their similarities in structure, were meant to insure complementarity in their parallel functions. There was no duplication of roles, since duties were clearly described and delineated.’ (48)
	‘One of the major functions of the omu and her cabinet was to oversee the community market, which was held every four days.’ (48)

Name: Awo
Description: 'A policewoman (awo), who was responsible for seeing that the fixed prices and taboos in the market were observed; she arrested offenders and brought them before the omu’s court of justice.’ (49)

Name: Otu umuada
Description:
A political pressure group of married, unmarried, widowed, and divorced daughters of a lineage or village group.

	‘The otu umuada included all the married, unmarried, widowed, and divorced daughters of a lineage or village group. These women acted as political pressure groups in their natal villages in order to achieve desired objectives. They stopped quarrels and prevented wars. So powerful was their reputation that their natal villages had to reckon with them and their possible reaction to every major decision. As daughters of the lineage, their social position was significantly higher than that of the inyemedi. The former had the acknowledged prerogative of addressing the latter as “our wives,” which in this patriarchal society indicated a lower status. The otu umuada could demand homage or duties from the out inyemedi, and they would be obliged to comply. Apparently a spirit of goodwill and “sweet rivalry” surrounded such demands.’ (52)
	‘The higher status of the umuada was further indicated by their ability to perform certain rites and sacrifices. Their leader, the most senior ada of the lineage – the ada-ebo – had the duty of performing the final absolution rites for a new bride. The bride had to confess any clandestine affairs she had had since becoming affianced to her husband. If the ada-ebo was satisfied with the confession, she had the prerogative of granting absolution to the bride from the sins of her “previous life” through the performance of sacrifices. Moreover, the ada-ebo received confessions from adulterous lineage wives and performed purificatory rites for them; she also carried out purifying rituals in lineage houses and places regarded as polluted.’ (52)

Name: Otu inyemedi
Description:
A female assembly which was lower than the otu umuada

	‘As is the case with women in other patrilocal societies, Igbo women had few rights in their marital villages. Though their children had full membership in the lineage, they themselves continued to be regarded as strangers.’ (52-53)
	‘At the head of the otu inyemedi was the anasi, the most senior wife of the village or lineage in terms of length of marriage.’ (53)
	‘At the meetings of the otu inymedi, decisions were made on how to help fellow wives in times of illness or stress, and on how to keep lineage or village streams and markets clean.

Name: Anasi
Description: ‘The anasi ran the biggest “household” of all the lineage wives. She gathered her co-wives together, presided over meetings, advised or admonished women, and generally mothered everybody.’ (53)

Name: Amanyanabo
Communities: Ijo of the Eastern Niger Delta
Description: “Owner of the town”. Chosen partly for his personal ability and partly because he belonged to the lineage of the founder.

Name: Assembly of House Heads
Communities: Ijo of the Eastern Niger Delta
Description: Assembly of House chiefs, with each house being a different “trading company” - although they maintained political and administrative
Institutional links: Acting together with the Amanyanabo (according to Horton, reference at Princewill [Hansen], 536)

Name: Stadtrat
Communities: Imperial and Free Towns of the Holy Roman Empire
Description: City council, most often governed by two mayors (Burgermeister). The number of councillors (Ratsherren) varied from town to town and so did the ways of electing them.

Name: Burgermeister
Communities: Imperial and Free Towns of the Holy Roman Empire
Description: Mayor, in charge of ruling the Stadtrat - usually two of them

Name: Ratsherren
Communities: Imperial and Free Towns of the Holy Roman Empire
Description: Councillors. Wealthy citizens. Their election depended differently from city to city

Name: Guilds' representatives
Communities: Imperial and Free Towns of the Holy Roman Empire
Description: They were admitted into the councils, sometimes able to transform the government's body. However, the governing body mostly remained in the hands of an oligarchy
Institutional links: Members (probably a minority) of the Stadtrat

Name: Local clan houses
Description: All decisions made by consensus among all the clan members, and all clan houses were represented in the Women’s Clan Council
Institutional links: Represented in the Women's clan council

Name: Women's clan council
Description:
All council houses represented here. It is an elected body presided over by the Jigonsaseh.

The men might only discuss an issue after the women had gone over it, which made the Women’s Clan Council the more powerful one— their deliberations effectively set the men’s agenda. Similarly, if the Men’s Grand Council did not dispose of an issue in the way that the Women’s Clan Council preferred, the women could take up the matter anew, reformulate it, and send it back to the men for reconsideration. This means the women’s council retained what amounted to a judicial review of men’s actions, and could stop them; the men’s council could not do the same to the women’s actions. 

Decides on war and peace
Institutional links: Sets the agenda for the men's grand council and operates as second chamber

Name: Men's grand council
Description: Made up of nations, not clans. represents the "federal" level. The men might only discuss an issue after the women had gone over it, which made the Women’s Clan Council the more powerful one— their deliberations effectively set the men’s agenda
Institutional links: Receives agenda from the women's clan council

Name: Hereditary chiefs
Description:
Their ‘job was to protect the “Innocents,” resolve conflict, and manage inter-national negotiations’ (306)

‘Hereditary chiefs were selected exclusively by women for specific council seats held by the clans’ (306)
Institutional links: ‘Hereditary chiefs were selected exclusively by women for specific council seats held by the clans’ (306)

Name: Merit chiefs
Description:
Their ‘selection was based on their various services to the community’ (306)

'selected exclusively by men; their selection was based on their merit, although hereditarily seats did not exist. For men, in addition to showing mature judgement, one of the ways to earn merit was by acting as a war chief, a position chosen by men after women had given war a go-ahead’ (306)

Name: War council
Description: ‘A feud took place after being decided upon in the war council. In this council, lines of relationship played no role since the merit chief, who sat in the war council, was not elected on the basis of clan structures. Thus, feuds were the formal reason for the resolutions of war council, but often this masked the young men’s thirst for adventure and ambitions for advancement. Feuds were carried out based on private initiative of volunteers, and whether or not a feud actually went forward depended completely on the war chief ’s popularity. He would dig up the hatchet (a red-painted tomahawk decorated with red feathers) and plunge it into the village war post. Then, fully adorned and emitting loud war cries, he would begin the war dance. By then, everyone in the village knew that a feud was planned, and those who voluntarily chose to follow the chief joined in the war dance. However, just as often, no one danced with him, and he went home in disgrace.’ (307-308)

Name: Owachira
Description:
House-based council, deals with household matters as well as general policy. The chosen representatives of the Ohwachira participated in clan, town, and federal politics. 

All political opinion and decision-making was based on household councils. Thus, the social and political order presented itself not as a top-down domination, but as a network based on consensus building from below.’
Institutional links: Its representatives participate in all the other councils

Name: Royaneh
Description:
Chiefmaker

She would have ‘the right to bestow a Peace Chief, or Sachem title’ (309)

Name: Sachem
Description: Peace Chief in the Men’s Grand Council
Institutional links: Peace Chief in the Men’s Grand Council

Name: mung
Description:
Village-like territory, where the village republics or gumlao governed. 
"A mung is a territory comprising a number of lineages of equal status. No one lineage is innately superior to others" (pg 204, Leach)

Name: Council of Elders
Description: Judicial authority rests with the Council. It is made up of the representatives of each lineage.
Institutional links: Chooses the Agyi, or village chief

Name: agyi
Description: This is the village chief. His "position is not strictly hereditary." Chosen by the Council of Elders

Name: bawmung
Description: The chief's (agyi's) subordinate, who would frequently succeed the chief. Often had as much real power as the chief

Name: Mother
Description:
The progenitor and head of the clan

‘The mother is not only the progenitor and head of the clan, but in her role as family priest also embodies a unifying principle. Responsibility for all family rituals lies with her, including the enormously important ceremonies for the dead. She is also custodian of all clan property: the communal house and land, and the income from the work of all the clan members. She inherits her position of official successor to the previous clan mother— her own mother. She is custodian of the clan’s property—not with an eye to her own gain, but for the whole clan, for whose well-being she is responsible. She guides distribution of the common wealth, taking care that it is shared out equally, and according to the needs of each, in a give-and-take economy that could well be called a clan internal “gift economy.” Her responsibility is based on natural bonds, not on abstraction, since all of the clan members are her sisters and brothers, her daughters and sons, for whom she cares. In the clan house, among her close relatives she is possessed of a natural authority, rather than a power over them, as encountered in patriarchal domination roles, where people’s needs and wants are not considered. Natural authority means, on her part, giving advice and, on their part, voluntary choice about accepting it or not: a relationship that develops out of family respect. In the clan house she has no staff of enforcement (no police, no army) to make her suggestions into commands.’

Name: Ka Khatduh
Description:
The youngest daughter ‘who takes over the entire ancestral property and the material as well as the spiritual responsibility for the “Kur,” 

	The youngest daughter ‘who takes over the entire ancestral property and the material as well as the spiritual responsibility for the “Kur,” or clan: it is the principle of ultima-geniture. She is supported by her eldest maternal uncle, who carries out the actual management and execution of clan property following the consensus of all clan members. The Ka Khatduh is now the new head and priestess of the clan (sub-clan, lineage) and begins her duties with the funeral rites for her revered dead mother, whose devoted support she was until the last.’ (48-49)
	‘Only in this non-patriarchal sense is the Ka Khatduh the head of the clan, and she never exercises her power through force. She is respected by the clan members, her sisters and daughters, her brothers and sons without coercion. In today’s politically aware climate, many Khasi men consider their matriarchal system to be the strength of their culture; a culture that has survived many thousands of years and holds the key to their ethnic identity.’ (52)
Institutional links: Daughter of head of clan, to succeed her.

Name: U Kni
Description:
‘Eldest brother and protector of his sisters.’

	‘The U Kni is the public representative of the clan at the council meetings, or “durbars,” as well as performing other representative functions.’ (51)
	‘the U Kni’s role is that of a delegate rather than a ruler. The clan would never permit him to exceed the boundaries of this purely executive role by taking steps of his own.’ (52)
Institutional links: Public representative of the clan at the council

Name: Durbar Iing
Description:
The family council. 

‘The clan house is the basic political unit, where decisions are made by consensus in the “Durbar Iing,” or family council, which then sends out senior male clan members to represent them in the “Durbar Kur,” or clan council. (51) The clan councils in turn send male representatives out to the “Durbar Shnong,” or local council. 

The British colonial government later superimposed a district council, which is a formal justice institution; this took away from the local councils the power to settle cases by consensus.’ (51-52)
Institutional links: Sends representatives to the clan council

Name: Syiem
Description:
Chief or king

‘The role of the Khasi head-persons is a good example: the oldest clans may install the “Syiems” (chiefs, or kings) in the various districts that comprise Khasi Land. Using the case of the well-researched district of Khyrim, we can outline the pattern of this “Syiemship.” The Syiem of Khyrim is the son of the “Syiem Sad,” the high priestess of Khyrim. Not he, but rather she, is the actual head of the people; she allows her son or nephew to act as her delegate.19 She owns the large royal house, in which a sacred column functions as an axis that designates the center of the (Khasi) world. Symbolically speaking, she lives right at the center of the world. Every official sacrifice ceremony begins through her, at the sacred column, and ends there as well.20 She is the keeper of the symbols: without the crown and all the sacred tools and sacrificial animals no sacrifice can be celebrated. She always performs the first sacrificial act in the house; afterwards, she turns the tools and the animals over to the Syiem, her son, and lets him continue the ceremony outside. This allows her to watch him from her house’ (53)
Institutional links: Oldest son of the high priestess, he acts as her delegate

Name: Durbar Kur
Description:
Clan council

They ‘send male representatives out to the “Durbar Shnong,” or local council.’ (52)
Institutional links: Sends representatives to the local council

Name: Durbar Shnong
Description: Local council

Name: Magistracies
Description:
Boards of magistrates 

Attestation ranges across cities, but there is evidence of Praetors (boards of two), Aediles and Quaestors; Censors. probably organized in a cursus honorum.
Institutional links: Connected with Priesthoods, and often occupied by the same people and families.

Name: Priesthoods
Description: Magistrates performing religious functions
Institutional links: Connected with political magistracies, and often occupied by the same people and families.

Name: Senate
Description:
Council of former magistrates

"the standard features [of political institutions in the city states] were annual magistracies, elected by a popular assemby, and a senate or council of former office holders." (p. 221)

Name: Popular Assembly
Description:
Assembly of the people

"the standard features [of political institutions in the city states] were annual magistracies, elected by a popular assemby, and a senate or council of former office holders." (p. 221)

Name: Tribal Council
Description:
Tribal council

-	“In the government of the tribe at present, all matters of importance are submitted to a council, which is held whenever any one gives a feast, or during the time of the ceremonials of the tamanawas.” (Swan, p. 53)
-	“The old men on these occasions generally do all the talking, although women are permitted to speak on matters where they are concerned.” (Swan, p. 53)

Name: En (malkum)
Description: King, Chief of state and head of the royal household
Institutional links: First hierarchic order of the palatial sector. Advised by many royal attendants and elite officials.

Name: Ø
Description:
Minister, Head of the "lugal council."

Functions: army general, head of the palatial administration, tax collector, overseer of merchants.

Emerges late, roughly in the last 20 years in the period under consideration. Eventually, it becomes an hereditary position. "The figure of the minister (O) apparently emerged as a sort of 'primus inter pares' within the council of the lugals, and gained preeminence during the reigns of the last two kings of Ebla, when the position of minister became a de fact hereditary role." Benati, 40.
Institutional links: Head of the lugals, with chief executive role.

Name: Lugal
Description:
District Governor.

Heads of noble families, overseers of palatine craft industries, tax collectors, managers of palatine flocks, military commanders, diplomatic envoys. 

Between 10 and 20 in number (based on Archi 2023)

Name: Abba
Description:
Elder, Heads of local communities. 

Functions: diplomatic envoys, tax collectors.

Unclear how exactly they governed the local units.
Institutional links: Politically representative of local communities and embedded into the palatial organization (live in the palace). Participate in the Lugal council.

Name: Lugal Council
Description:
Informal council made up of Lugals and Abbas.  

No info about institutional mechanisms within. Probably consultative, dealing with disputes arising from local community demands and from the King.
Institutional links: Made up of Lugals and Abbas.

Name: Notables/ Officials
Description:
Officials. 

Made of: ugula-rank administrators, na-se (free individuals), maskim (travelling agents), ir (king's servants), di-kud (judges)

Name: Judges
Description:
Groups of two judges, traveling around the country and resolving disputes.

Belong to noble families, unclear if the same families that provide the Lugals. no info on selection mechanisms.
Institutional links: Probably, originally selected by the central administration and hereditary.

Name: King
Description:
King. 

Top political figure in the kingdom.

Name: Vassal rulers
Description: Rulers of individual territories (city-states) inhabited by local syrians.

Name: Tribal chiefs
Description:
Rulers of individual groups of semi-nomadic Amorites tribes. Chosen by the community, but his rule depends on the consent of the king. 

Selection probably had a hereditary element mixed with merit (probably having to do with military power)
Institutional links: Rule independently of the kins within a mutual consent structure.

Name: Šapitum
Description:
Governors of district, with individual laputtum (deputies) for centralized administration. 

Fleming, D.E., p.25 ("The districts (halsum) of the inherited Banks-of-the-Euphrates (Ah Purattim) dominions were overseen by governors (sapitum), each with his own local palace and deputy (laputtum) to allow centralized administration.")

Name: Laputtum
Description:
Deputy to the governor 

Fleming, D.E., p.25 ("The districts (halsum) of the inherited Banks-of-the-Euphrates (Ah Purattim) dominions were overseen by governorns (sapitum), each with his own local palace and deputy (laputtum) to allow centralized administration.")

Name: Halsums
Description:
Districts with local palace, governor and administrative centre

Fleming, D.E., p.11 ("the farming country along the rivers was governed within a system of "districts" called halsums, each with its own local palace administrative center and governor.")

Name: Tahtamum
Description:
Town council among the local syrians, made up of local notables.

Autonomous governing body (not necessarily called by the king).

Name: Rihsum
Description:
Assembly of elders and notables.

Probably, can either be a gathering of elders and chiefs for political decision-making, or an occasional meeting of mobile pastoralists for dispute resolution.

Fleming, D.E., p. 203 ("Rihsum is associated with the assembly of pastoralists. It is never defined by towns, and it designates the talks or negotiations that occur within a meeting of mobile pastoralists, not the assembly as such") | Fleming, D.E., p. 208-209 ("Rihsum (...) relates only to gatherings of tent-dwellings 'Hana' pastoralists, sometimes at the initiative of outside authorities.") | Fleming, D.E., p. 209 ("It seems clear from the texts that the rihsum is not the assembly but the talks that ensue (...) The meeting comes first and the rihsum follows, as contingent on and separate from the act of gathering. The focus of the rihsum appears to be conversation (...) the term applies specifically to talks related to interactions between separate groups.") | Fleming, D.E., 210 ("It is not always clear that the rihsum is so inclusive, however (...) The rishum is often defined by the participation of tribal peoples, sometimes likely to be mobile pastoralists (...) it shows no particular attachment to one of the paired tribal confederacies") Fleming, D.E., p. 211 ("More inclusive participation does, however, seem to characterize the tribal rihsum, especially as associated with the pastoralist elements of the Yaminite and Sim'alite tribal groups") | Fleming, D.E., p. 234 ("One reference to the rihsum talks displays what may be the assembly of an entire tribal population") |Fleming, D.E., p. 238 ("The tribal meetings of the rihsum")
Institutional links: Made up of elders and notables

Name: (Tribal) Elders
Description:
Members of a council with fixed functions within tribal groups.

Fleming, D. E., p. 190 ("Discussions of such Mesopotamian 'elders' often assume that they functioned as part of a 'council', a word that calls forth an image of institutions with some standing status, who perform some regualar tasks and meet on some predictable basis. In fact, elder terminology usually represented a broad classification status, not the designation of a permanent individual title, whose assembled bearers would meet as a council of fixed function") | FUNCTIONS OF THE ELDERS DESCRIBED FROM P. 191 TO 192 AND INCLUDE: designation of senior leadership distinct from king; representative of king, for royal authority or administration; representative of the town; negotiation with outsiders; witnessing of legal proceedings; rituals | Fleming, D.E., 193 ("One letter seems to use word elders for a gathering that includes several kings") | Fleming, D.E., p. 195 ("When scholars speak of a council of elders, this is not usually interpreted asa a cabinet of senior advisers or a selection of high administrators and royal henchmen. IN some cases, however, the term is used with just this sort of application") | Fleming, D.E., p. 196 ("They have a stature that can somehow stand on its own as well, so that they retain interim authority in the selection of a replacement [to the king]")

Name: Puhrum
Description:
Assembly of the people. Informal meetings called occasionally to ratify decisions before the whole population.

Common around Mesopotamia

Name: Yaminites
Description:
'Right hand' tribe confederacy

Fleming, D.E.,p. 24 ("The tribal people within the Mari kingdom belonged mainly to two confederations that together represented a coherent duality: the Sim'alites of the 'left hand' and the Yaminites of the 'right hand'") | Fleming, D.E., p.24 ("The entire Yaminite people are defined as a confederation of five tribes, each with its own ruler") | Fleming, D.E., p.26 ("I call the overarching Yaminite and Sim'alite groups 'tribal confederacies', suitable to both their evident size and[...]")
Institutional links:
Opposed to the Sim'alites

Confederacy of five tribes, each with its own ruler and deputies

Name: Sim'alites
Description:
'Left hand' tribe confederacy

Fleming, D.E.,p. 24 ("The tribal people within the Mari kingdom belonged mainly to two confederations that together represented a coherent duality: the Sim'alites of the 'left hand' and the Yaminites of the 'right hand'") | Fleming, D.E., p.24 ("The entire Yaminite people are defined as a confederation of five tribes, each with its own ruler") | Fleming, D.E., p.26 ("I call the overarching Yaminite and Sim'alite groups 'tribal confederacies', suitable to both their evident size and[...]")
Institutional links:
Opposed to the Yaminites

Confederacy of tribes, which number is not specified

Name: Sugagum
Description:
Sim'alite town leader

Fleming, D.E., p.11 ("the midlevel leaders of both the settled towns and the mobile pastoralists had the same title (sugāgum)") Fleming, D.E., p.25 ("[Hana] acknowledged a leader ('sugagum') who was affiliated only by tribe, not town [...]") | Fleming, D.E., p.25 ("the sugagums are best known at Mari as town leaders.") | Fleming, D.E., p.25 ("The sugagum plays an important role in distinguishing Yaminite and Sim'alite political structures, at the same time as he is the one individual leader whose very office can be defined by the town he serves")
Institutional links:
Specifics of the office defined by the town in which the sugagum serves.

Lower-level sugagums served under the merhums

Name: Merhum
Description:
Sim'alite chief of pasture

Fleming, D.E.., p.11 ("Zimri-Lim gave direct authority to his Sim'alite tribal chiefs of pasture, called merhûms, who led the mobile pastoralist component of his people, most often called simply "Hana" ("tent-dwellers"). Under Zimri-Lim, the whole of the "land" (matum) that he ruled was identified by the tent-dwellers of the Sim'alite tribal population, but the Kingdom as a whole was divided into two parts") | Fleming, D.E., p.25 ("[...]and two Sim'alite chiefs of pasture (merhums) served as respected leaders over the entire tent-dwelling (Hana ndr) tribal population. They reported only to Zimri-Lim and his immediate cabinet of top advisers, and stood outside the district system. [...] the merhums had to join in tribal meetings and await the collective decision (i.e., see the rihsum")
Institutional links:
'Reported directly to the king and his inner circle' (Fleming (2004), p. 76)

'Assisted by his own sugagums.' (p. 77)

'held influence on a par with the highest officials of Zimri-Lim’s inner circle.' (p. 79)

Name: Nagari
Description: The equivalent of a village, made up of at least 4 suku (clans). Governed by a panghulu according to the rules of the nagari constitution.

Name: Suku
Description:
Assembly of the clan 

The population of a nagari was organized in matrilineages, each of which was affiliated with a suku or clan. The leader of the suku was informally chosen by deliberation and consensus within the rumah gadangs making up the suku.

The suku can be considered a political assembly, which met fairly infrequently, usually for the purpose of electing a leader.
Institutional links: The matriarch of each suku was a member of the panghulu.

Name: Rumah gadang
Description: The family long house, which was under the control of a matriarch, and passed on to the eldest daughter after her death. There were living compartments for each women, where their husbands came as guests for the night. Men resided in the local mosque after coming of age.
Institutional links: multiple rumah gadangs related by kin made up a suku

Name: Panghulu
Description:
Matriarchal council. Group of matrilineal leaders governing the nagari, who made political decisions and resolved disputes. Each member of the panghulu had an equal vote when it came to making a decision, and since it was generally made of odd numbers, the will of the majority was carried out. 

"the panghulu retains the highest authority also in property affairs. No transfer of any buah gadang property, share-cropping agreements excepted, may occur without its taking cognizance." (pg. 66)
Institutional links: The matriarch of each suku had a place In the panghulu. She was replaced after her death by the next matriarch of the suku.

Name: Buah gadang
Description:
Administrative and social unit

Defined as " a matrilineal descent group (MDG) comprising only persons who trace common matrilineal descent from one apical ancestress." 
They were characterized as being 'saparuik' - 'of one womb.' 
Essentially, each buah gadang could trace a common ancestor and eventually split into kaums and then into suku. 
Thus, a buah gadang was also defined as a collection of the informal 'kaums' or groups. On average 3-4 kaums made a buah gadang (pg. 65)
Being a member of a buah gadang allowed the descendants of former slaves to acquire citizenship of the nagari. 

Land and agricultural produce were usually owned collectively by a kaum. In the case of disputed land between kaums, the buah gadang, which was made of kaums attempted to resolve it amicably. However, if this did not happen, the matter was taken to the matriarchal council or panghulu, who had the final word. 

"Their mutual relationships, hierarchical order, and the formation of more inclusive groups of buah gadang are regulated in the nagari's constitution." The constitution essentially gave the power of forming new buah gadangs or adding new citizens to existent buah gadangs to the panghulu since they were the nagari's political leaders.

Name: Kaum
Description: Kaum is a social group within the buah gadang, headed by an informally chosen kaum leader, memak kepala waris. There were strong trust relations within the kaum and they frequently held land jointly.
Institutional links: Suku and kaum may seem similar, but suku was based on genetic relationships, and it was an exogamous entitity, i.e, marriages within the suku were prohibited. Furthermore, the kaum was a socio-economic grouping whereas the suku was represented politically at the level of a nagari.

Name: Adat
Description:
The overarching royalty who exercised control over the nagaris, but were devoid of any real power. 
"Little is known about the position of the kings. "(pg. 58) 
Historically believed to have devised the nagari constitution which was adapted to each village. 
"Succession to their office was patrilineal, a contrast with the matrilineal organization of the suku."
Institutional links: The adat was believed to have consulted the panghulu while devising the original nagari constitution, which means that female interests were represented even at this level.

Name: Council of four
Description:
Council of four advisers, among which there was a chief adviser, assisting the ruler. They were probably close relatives, depicted as priests in the codices. They were in charge of the sacred bundles of the city-state and the chief adviser was also in charge of military affairs. 
“(Spores, (1984) 77) has characterised the political system of the Mixtec city-state as one in which the ruler communicated directly with a small group of advisers and noble administrators. It lacked the large and cumbersome bureaucracy characteristic of macro-states where edicts from the ruler filter down through many bureaucratic levels”
“Codice de Yanhuitlan shows a courtyard of his palace with at least four advisers discussing affairs of the city-state with a group of more than 50 noble administrators (Sepulveda y Herrera (1994), 99), 572”

Name: king or queen
Description: Hereditary King or Queen
Institutional links: Assisted by the council of four advisers

Name: Nobles
Description: Govern the barrios, or neighborhoods. Are appointed by the ruler and are probably their close relatives

Name: Informal Council
Description:
Informal Council was formed by male heads of each settlement. 
They deliberated about important tribal affairs. (Fathauer, p. 109)

(There is not much information on the informal council as a majority of the literature on Mohave is regards their warfare culture and power of dreams)
Institutional links:
Featured male heads and Kwaxot.
Used to solve internal tribal affairs.

Name: Kwaxot - Main Tribal Leader
Description:
"Kwaxot" was the main tribal leader, performing religious functions that contributed to tribal integration. (Fathauer, p. 109)

-	The custodian of the scalps (kwaxot) was the major religious official. (Fathauer, p. 98)
-      He did not go on the warpath but presided at the victory celebrations and cared for the scalps and female prisoners brought back by the warriors. (Fathauer, p. 98)
-	It is clear that the status of kwaxot formed the nexus of two great themes of Mohave life: warfare and tribal continuity through fertility. (Fathauer, p. 108)
-	Thus the statuses of kwaxot and axwe satumac (scalper) formed the structural connections for three extremely important themes of Mohave life: warfare, sickness, and tribal continuity through fertility. (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	The kwaxot and scalper were in charge of tribal war expeditions as revealed by the fact that scalps could not be taken in the absence of the scalper and that the kwaxot cared for these trophies in the interest of the entire tribe. (Fathauer, p. 110)
-	The ultimate determinant of the statuses a man would occupy depended upon his dreams. (Fathauer, p. 110)
- The tribal chief was not a kwanami and did not go to war. (Stewart, p. 260)
Institutional links: Partook in both Informal Council and Conference for Warfare.

Name: Conference for Warfare
Description: "Conference for Warfare" was where officials such as Kwaxot, Scalper, Head Kwanamis, Braves (Kwanamis) and spies solicited the opinions of some of the wise old men of the tribe before engaging in warfare. (Fathauer p. 98)
Institutional links:
Featured Kwaxot, Scalper, Braves and Head Kwanamis.
Used to consult with wise old men regards warfare.

Name: Scalper (ahwe somadj/axwe satumac) - Shaman
Description:
The scalper (ahwe somadj/axwe satumac) was a Shaman that accompanied large war parties and doctored the warriors, and who had dreamed of special powers that made him the only one capable of scalping the enemy. 

-      The scalper, who was also a shaman, exemplified the connection between warfare and the Mohave "racist" philosophy in which non-contamination with foreign blood was always a primary consideration. (Fathauer, p. 108)
-	Warfare was a means of demonstrating tribal prowess and superiority to other tribes. (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	Thus the statuses of kwaxot and axwe satumac (scalper) formed the structural connections for three extremely important themes of Mohave life: warfare, sickness, and tribal continuity through fertility. (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	The scalper was also a tribal official, since only one man occupied this status at any one time. (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	The kwaxot and scalper were in charge of tribal war expeditions as revealed by the fact that scalps could not be taken in the absence of the scalper and that the kwaxot cared for these trophies in the interest of the entire tribe. (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	The ultimate determinant of the statuses a man would occupy depended upon his dreams. (Fathauer, p. 110)
