- Mohave warriors feared the magical potency of an enemy scalp; if a man should touch it he would go insane and "holler in the night." (Stewart, p. 269)
- Consequently, scalping was performed only by a special scalper, the ahwe somadj ("dream[er] of foes"), who was a shaman rather than a warrior, and who, provided he underwent purification, was unharmed by contact with the scalp. (Stewart, p. 269)
- The ahwe somadj, who dreamed his power to scalp, also doctored warriors who had fallen ill due to contact with the enemy. (Stewart, p. 269)
-  When the scalper spied an enemy with a desirable head of
 hair, he would knock him down, break his neck, and cut off the head with a stone knife. (Stewart, p. 269)

Name: Braves (Kwanamis)
Description:
When warfare was imminent, the braves (k"anami), who were scattered throughout the valley, became important tribal officials. (Fathauer, p. 98)
In more peaceful times, braves also had a role to play - the braves had some local autonomy in dealing with raids and small revenge parties. (Fathauer, p. 109)
- Braves dreamed special war powers. (Fathauer, p. 99)
- Kwanamis were responsible for the recurrent hostilities and over whom there was no effective control (Stewart, p. 257)
Institutional links:
Were led by Head Kwanamis.
Were doctored by Scalper.

Name: Chief for dealing with White People
Description:
The status of chief developed as a result of the necessity of dealing with the Whites in an organized manner. (Fathauer, p. 110)

-	As indicated earlier in this paper, the chief was excluded from warlike activities. (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	This may not be an accurate reflection of aboriginal conditions. (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	The status of xanidal apparently did not exist prior to fairly extensive White contact.  (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	According to several informants, the first chief was chosen after the Whites came, when it became necessary to deal with them. (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	The status was fitted into the aboriginal pattern, but not completely, since, although the chief was supposed to dream his power, the office also became hereditary. (Fathauer, p. 109) 
-	The first chief was selected because he was "lucky" in his dealings with the Whites. (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	It appears probable that the status of chief represented an elaboration of the rather vaguely defined status of pataxan, local group leader. (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	The principal tribal status of religious leadership, kwaxot, declined in importance rapidly when the culture began to change under the impact of Whites. (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	The new status of chief lacked the connections with religion and war that characterized that of kwaxot, and appears to have been based upon the status of pataxan, or local group leader. (Fathauer, p. 110)

Name: Yakatha'alya women
Description:
Minor status of "yakatha'alya" was occupied by females. (Fathauer p. 109)
The position was not an important one but it did serve to give expression to the female interest in the activity of warfare. (Fathauer, p. 109)
They danced at the scalp ceremonies and shamed the able-bodied men who had not gone to war. (Fathauer, p. 109)
-	In order to occupy this position a dream was necessary, but it was not a very powerful one, according to informants. (Fathauer, p. 109)

Name: Head Kwanamis - War Chiefs
Description:
The head of a war party that recruited and instructed Braves. Head Kwanami did not answer to Kwaxot and had limited control over the Braves.

- Two or three men in the tribe ranked as head kwanamis or war chiefs, for whom there was no name other than kwanami.  (Stewart, p. 260)
- Like other kwanamis, they theoretically attained their positions through proper dreaming.  (Stewart, p. 260)
- Each war party was conducted by a head kwanami, whose powers were minimal and not clearly formulated, although he was not responsible to the tribal chief.  (Stewart, p. 260)
- The head kwanami acted as a leader and officer on the war party, and when the party approached an enemy camp he stopped the warriors and gave them instructions relative to the attack. (Stewart, p. 260)
- Several months often elapsed after the return of the scouts before a war party set out. (Stewart, p. 266)
- A few days before the party was scheduled to leave the head kwanami would call a meeting, at which song cycles were sung, and at which warriors were given an opportunity to volunteer for the campaign. (Stewart, p. 266)
Institutional links:
Led Kwanamis.
Were not responsible to Kwaxot.

Name: kurultay
Description:
A central elite assembly.

- Assembly to elect new leaders and discuss important policy matters (Stasavage)

- Sometimes these assemblies were genuinely plenary and consisted of representatives of all the steppe nation's tribes. (Fletcher, p. 26)
- In such circumstances they may occasionally have been electoral. (p.26)
- But the convening of a khuriltai without its outcome being a foregone conclusion was probably rare. (Fletcher, p. 26)
- Much more commonly they were merely acclamation ceremonies for a given candidate, acting in the steppe nation's name. (Fletcher, p. 26)
Institutional links: Elected and/or legitimised the new Khan

Name: Shaman
Description:
A person with supernatural abilities

- Being in touch with the supernatural world, the shaman's support for a given candidate for the chieftaincy might carry weight if the shaman decided to involve himself in the succession choice. (Fletcher, p. 18)
- Shamans chose auspicious days for battle, healed the physically sick and the emotionally disturbed, enabled childless women to conceive, warded off evil, and the like. (Fletcher, p. 18)
- Their roles probably ranged from that of nokor of the tribal chief to one of rivalling him for authority. (Fletcher, p. 18)
- Sometimes the shaman might himself become the tribal chief, combining both roles in one person. (Fletcher, p. 18)
Institutional links:
- Belonged to Shamanic "guild"
- Counterbalanced and confirmed chief's authority 
- In some cases, combined the role of Shaman and Tribal Chief into one

Name: Shamanic "Guild"
Description:
A guild that consisted of Shamans from different tribes
- The shaman commonly belonged to a kind of shamanic "guild," which provided links with other tribes that could benefit the chief and the tribal membership-links that bolstered the shaman's influence within the tribe (Fletcher, p. 18)
Institutional links: Consisted of Shamans from different tribes

Name: Khan
Description:
A leader with the highest authority in the steppe.

- The steppe khan was surrounded by no pomp, ceremony, or mystery to clothe his kingship in a nimbus of the divine in the way that Iranian, Roman, or Chinese emperors were revealed. (Fletcher, p. 23)
- His purpose was down-to-earth: to obtain and distribute wealth. (Fletcher, p. 23)
- Great emphasis was placed on the quality of generosity. (Fletcher, p. 23)
- Even more basic was the quality of warrior and leader of men. (Fletcher, p. 23)
- As the head of a confederation, the ruler might not have to fight, but as autocrat of a steppe empire, the essential qualities were martial ones. (Fletcher, p. 23)
- An "imperial" khan had to lead his subjects to success on the field of battle and in the extortion of wealth from sedentary governments. (Fletcher, p. 23)

- So personal was this bond [between Khan and the tribal chief]-upon which the integrity of the steppe empire was based- that at the khan's death, unless his successor recreated the empire on a similar personal basis, the empire soon dissolved. (Fletcher, p. 23)
- In a steppe empire-as opposed to a confederation-the bond between the khan and the tribal chief was the bond between leader and follower, between general and regimental commander-but between the two men as persons not as offices (Fletcher, p. 23)
Institutional links: Khan had to have a personal bond with Tribal chiefs to have their tribes under his authority

Name: Nokor
Description:
Personal supporters (of clan's leaders, tribal chiefs, Khans or candidates for these leading roles). 

-   But in a large tribe, rival candidates for the chieftaincy, each closely backed by his own retinue of personal supporters (nokor), might occasionally split the tribe, either temporarily or permanently. (Fletcher, p. 17)
-  In a succession struggle, the rival candidates and their nokor competed for the support of the tribe's leading men and formed factions that could either compromise or fight. (Fletcher, p. 17-18)
-  Not just members of the chiefly lineage but also leaders of the tribe's noble clans not infrequently surrounded themselves with nokor and held a potential for usurping the chieftaincy or breaking away, taking their haran with them, and forming a new tribe. (Fletcher, p. 18)
-  Like the tribal chiefs and nobles, the supratribal ruler and all contestants for his office had personal retinues of nokor who served their master as his eyes and ears and hands-as military commanders, administrators, secret or public agents, and specialists of all kinds who formed the nucleus of what could become, if need be, an extended imperial administration. (Fletcher, p. 20)
- Nokor directed their master's personal guard-cum-household, being, as it were, his slaves and companions. (Fletcher, p. 20)
- They derived their power and authority exclusively from his
 person and might be recruited from any social origin, nomadic or sedentary, noble, commoner, or slave. (Fletcher, p. 20)
- But if they were noblemen, they were not likely to be tribal chiefs (although Chinggis Khan himself, after reaching a certain level of power, deviated from this pattern), inasmuch as the possession of an autonomous basis of power would make for an unreliable nokor. (Fletcher, p. 20)
Institutional links: Personal supporters (of clan's leaders, tribal chiefs, Khans or candidates for these leading roles).

Name: Tribal Chief
Description:
The head of the Tribe.

Role:
- Chief's main responsibilities were to provide leadership, assign pasture, and determine the routes of migration. (Fletcher, p. 19)

Succession:
- Chosen from the chiefly lineage, which was dominant amongst the clans (Fletcher, p. 17)
- Choice of the tribal chief was, in a manner of speaking, electoral, being governed by the principle of tanistry (Fletcher, p. 17)
- Principle of tanistry held that the tribe should be led by the best qualified member of the chiefly house (Fletcher, p. 17)
- At the chief's death, in other words, the succession did not pass automatically, in accordance with any principle of seniority such as primogeniture, but rather was supposed to go to the most competent of the eligible heirs. (Fletcher, p. 17)
- Unless the tribe was very large, most tribal interests were usually best served by a timely resolution of the succession question, and the tribal leaders must ordinarily have managed to keep disruptions to a minimum. (Fletcher, p. 17)
- But in a large tribe, rival candidates for the chieftaincy, each closely backed by his own retinue of personal supporters (nokor), might occasionally split the tribe, either temporarily or permanently. (Fletcher, p. 17)
- In a succession struggle, the rival candidates and their nokor competed for the support of the tribe's leading men and formed factions that could either compromise or fight. (Fletcher, p. 18)
- Nor were the rivals limited to the backing of members of their own tribe. If a tribe were part of a confederation, a given candidate might win the backing of the confederal ruler or other powerful elements within the confederation. (Fletcher, p. 18)
- Tribes or leading tribal families also commonly had special relationships with tribal (or even non-tribal) elements outside the confederation and sometimes even beyond the edges of the steppe. (Fletcher, p. 18)
- These too could be called upon for support or for asylum in the event that a given candidate met defeat. (Fletcher, p. 18)
Institutional links: His authority was counterbalanced and confirmed by Tribal Council; Legitimised and answered to Khan

Name: Tribal Council
Description:
Local elite councils.
- Tribal councils consisted of tribe's other leading men (Fletcher, p. 19)
- Their role was to elect a Chief
- Leading men were usually regarded as nobles (Fletcher, p. 16)

Name: Dabu
Description:
The matriarch of the clan

	‘She organises the agricultural work and distributes the food; she manages the clan’s communal property, which is handed over to her, both material and liquid, and sees to the expenses; she takes care of the guests and is the house priestess at all family ceremonies. She has, however, no special privileges that would contravene the principle of equality on which these societies are based, since she works just as hard as other family members do, and they all discuss the important events together. She can make no unilateral decisions about the community’s wealth. She not only arbitrate in clan conflicts, but also, until recently, the matriarchs of the different clans held important positions in the village councils as well.’ (108)
Institutional links: Holds important positions in the village councils

Name: Village Council
Description: Village councils. Dabu holds important positions

Name: Uilikande
Description: Chief
Institutional links: Head of the village (rainy seasons) or head of the band (dry seasons)

Name: Great Sun
Description: Had personal and arbitrary mechanisms of power, which were, however, often ignored by those below him. The further away from him his subordinates lived, the less power he held over them

Name: War Council
Description: Would often ignore the advice of the Great Sun
Institutional links: Would often ignore the advice of the Great Sun

Name: Governor of districts
Description: Governors of districts

Name: Assembly Houses
Description:
Nebelivka was divided into roughly fourteen Quarters. Each Quarter had at least one Assembly House. No single Quarter seemed to resemble any other Quarter in size or content. As such it seems that there was no centralization. Neighbours would come together in a localized, bottom-up decision-making process. There was a house, a neighbourhood, a Quarter and a city. The structure of the Assembly House also suggests that Nebelivka was not a hierarchical society ruled by elites as the Assembly Houses were bigger versions of the 'typical' Trypillia houses. 

- One of the key structuring elements of the Nebelivka plan is the series of larger-than-usual buildings provisionally termed ‘assembly houses’, on the assumption that these buildings were public places for meetings (Figure 1). (Chapman, p. 128)
- The judicious combination of as many of the multiple criteria as possible [see notes for the 8 criteria examples] has led to a preliminary partition of the Nebelivka mega-site into fourteen Quarters (Figure 1).
- It has been assumed that the location of single, paired, or groups of Assembly Houses was related to the structuring of domestic houses within the Quarters. (Chapman, p. 129)
- It follows, then, that the distance separating Assembly Houses in adjacent Quarters would signify locational regularities (or otherwise) in the overall planning of the Quarters. (Chapman, p. 129)
- This measure of the regularity of planning Quarters reveals a localized, bottom-up decision-making process rather than an overall ‘centralized planning’ that may have resulted in much more regular inter-Assembly Room spacing. (Chapman, p. 129)
- A basic analysis of some of the locational and dimensional ‘regularities’ found at Nebelivka shows how Quarters developed in such markedly different ways that no single Quarter resembled any other Quarter in size or content. (Chapman, p. 129)
- It is improbable that different partitioning of the mega-site would result in a different conclusion from this: namely, that the mega-site developed from the bottom-up within the overall constraints of the basic planning principles. (Chapman, p. 129)
- It is intriguing that such variability could have been produced within identical planning principles. (Chapman, p. 129)
- In short, the Nebelivka mega-structure is, in a sense, much more interesting than a ritual centre with all the trappings of a Late Neolithic temple (cf. Parţa: Lazarovici et al., 2001); it is a massive building with large versions of domestic features—‘mega-features’— but with few objects differentiating the building from ‘typical’ Trypillia houses. (Chapman, p. 127)
- Those expecting the architectural and artefactual reflections of a hierarchical society with elites ruling over thousands of inhabitants in a Trypillia mega-site will be disappointed. (Chapman, p. 127)
- The resultant interpretation of the Nebelivka mega-structure requires a much more subtle model of site depositional practices than we have so far managed to create. (Chapman, p. 127)
- We are left with a building of great size, with a strong element of internal spatial differentiation, but with very few special artefacts. (Chapman, p. 128) 
- There is still little doubt that this is a public building, where meetings, and even ceremonies, could have taken place. (Chapman, p. 128)
- The most obvious place for large meetings would have been the open central area, with its access to four major internal features—the podium, the fired clay bin, and the two largest Raised Areas. (Chapman, p. 128)
- In addition, there may have been access to a set of small drinking-cups at the East end of the central area. (Chapman, p. 128)
- But if those who attended the meetings brought their favourite objects with them, they seemed to have taken many of them away at the end of the ceremonies. (Chapman, p. 128)
- The strong impression at the end of the excavation was of a mega-structure which had imitated the fittings and features of a domestic house on a large scale, without differentiating the megastructure in an artefactual sense. (Chapman, p. 128)
- We can therefore conclude that Trypillia mega-structures did indeed materialize spatial differentiation without the additional elaboration of artefactual differentiation. (Chapman, p. 128)
- The results of the excavation of the Nebelivka mega-structure have interesting implications for our understanding of the question of Trypillia urbanism. (Chapman, p. 129)
- Rather than the creation of a completely new form of public buildings, with special functions materialized in dramatic, often monumental ways (e.g. the monumental temple complexes in the Late Chalcolithic and Early Bronze Age of southwest Asia (Matthews, 2009; Gates, 2011), Trypillian dwellers were content to reproduce their family houses en gros at certain strategic points of the settlement, with deposition on the same level as in family houses. (Chapman, p. 129)
- But the mega-structure was by no means the same as a ‘normal house’, especially in its paucity of food storage, production, heating, and cooking facilities. (Chapman, p. 129)
- Several principal features (e.g. podium, cruciform Raised Areas) of the mega-structure are also similar to the features well known from Trypillia houses—but the Nebelivka examples are much larger (the podium, the Raised Areas) and more numerous (the Raised Areas). (Chapman, p. 127)
- Preliminary research suggests that the fired clay bin, the largest Raised Area, and podium are the largest examples of their type so far known in the Trypillia culture. (Chapman, p. 127)
- It would appear that the basic elements of the Trypillia house have been borrowed and adapted to fit the great size of what remains a public building but one without the depositional characteristics of a ritual or administrative centre. (Chapman, p. 127)
- The layout of the rooms and internal features in both interpretations of the mega-structure does not fit any of the ‘typical’ domestic house layouts as defined by Chernovol (2012: figure 8.8). (Chapman, p. 127)
- The mega-structure would have been a monumental building, visible from several km on the South part of the micro-region. (Chapman, p. 127)
- Interpretation of the mega-structure: the architectural remains of the Nebelivka mega-structure, together with its associated artefact assemblage, pose an intriguing problem of interpretation. (Chapman, p. 125)
- Before our excavation, the teams shared an expectation of a large public building with a range of special finds, indicating some kind of administrative or ritual central place serving, at the very least, a cluster of houses in the South–East part of the mega-site. (Chapman, p. 125)
- The size of the structure is not in doubt and the excavated remains provided a close match to the 2009 geophysical plan. (Chapman, p. 125)
- However, there was only one part of the mega-structure with anything resembling monumental architectural features—the East threshold with possible monumental wall features (Chapman, p. 125)
- ... This means that anyone approaching the mega-structure from the East side would have been confronted by a 2 m±high wall, with a possibly monumental entrance at the top of a slope. (Chapman, p. 126)
- They would then have entered a loosely integrated structure which was partly roofed, partly open and with markedly different kinds of local ‘spaces’—large open areas, small open areas, larger ‘rooms’, smaller ‘rooms’, and ‘box rooms’. (Chapman, p. 126)
- The overall impression of the finds from the mega-structure is that there are few finds that differ greatly from the ‘typical’ Trypillia house assemblage. (Chapman, p. 126)
- The group of over twenty small fired clay cones is perhaps a sign of an administrative practice (Videiko, 1987: 32–33), but may also be interpreted as gaming pieces (Figure 20). (Chapman, p. 127)
- In general, there is little to make the mega-structure objects stand out from the typical artefact assemblage from a Trypillia house. (Chapman, p. 127)

Name: Banjar (Hamlet)
Description:
Considered the "fundamental civil community in Bali." (pg. 47)
The domain of its jurisdiction was laid out clearly in a constitution called awig-awig banjar (hamlet rules). It had a kilan banjar (council) and krama banjar (assembly).
This document was adapted slightly to suit the needs of the local hamlet, but otherwise remained constant. 
'The hamlet was responsible for public facilities' like road building, the upkeep of hamlet meeting houses, etc. (pg. 48)
It was in charge of 'local security' and 'the settlement of public disputes' as well. Furthermore, it 'regulated the transfer of 'personal property' and  'legitimized marriage and divorce' (pg. 49)
Institutional links: Administrative unit in the Dorpsre­ publiek (village republics)

Name: Kilan Banjar
Description:
Council of the hamlet.

- The krama banjar elected the kilan banjar, a set of leaders (the number of which varied from hamlet to hamlet). They were less like rulers and more like the agents of the krama banjar, since they were responsible for the execution of the decisions made by the krama banjar. There were no codified rules dictating their actions, but the kilan banjar followed its own mode of procedure based on past traditions.

Name: Krama banjar
Description:
Assembly of the hamlet.  

The krama banjar was composed of the citizenry of the hamlet. A man became a member of this after getting married or having his first child. This ensured that each family had a representative in it.
- The krama banjar met once every 35 days, but special meetings could be called. It made all the important policy decisions with consensus. 

- The krama banjar elected the kilan banjar, a set of leaders (the number of which varied from hamlet to hamlet). They were less like rulers and more like the agents of the krama banjar, since they were responsible for the execution of the decisions made by the krama banjar. There were no codified rules dictating their actions, but the kilan banjar followed its own mode of procedure based on past traditions. 
- The krama banjar was "the sovereign body in all hamlet affairs, ·punishing any incorrigible resistance to its authority, no matter how apparently trivial, by ostracism" Thus, the banjar enforced its decisions by criticising and shunning those who did not abide by its dictates
Institutional links: Elects leaders of the kilan banjar. it also sends representatives to the Pemaksan

Name: Subak (Irrigation society)
Description:
Group overseeing irrigation. 

Organised exactly like the hamlet with a krama subak and a kilan subak. However, in contrast with the krama banjar, "the members of the corporation (the krama subak) were, however, not co-residents, but co-proprietors- the owners of terraces irrigated from a single artificial watercourse" 

- the members of krama subak (irrigation assembly) did not include representation from all the village, but only large landowners and those who irrigated their terraces from a shared water source, making it an elite assembly. 


Furthermore, "Like the hamlet, the irrigation society could levy fines, exact punish­ments, settle disputes, own property, and determine its own policies" (p. 50)

The main function of this body was irrigation control. "The creation and maintenance of water works and the allot­ment of water among users were the central concerns of the subak as a whole." (pg. 50)
Moreover "the irrigation society engaged in purificatory ritual performances at special rice field and water-source temples; legitimated transfers of terrace ownership; gave or withheld per­ mission for new  terrace construction; and regulated the timing of the cultivation cycle" (pg. 51)

Name: Pemaksan
Description: A religious council "composed of the members of anywhere from one to perhaps nine or ten hamlets." Usually, it spanned across three or four contiguous hamlets, and was in charge of organising religious ceremonies and the upkeep of temples.
Institutional links: The krama banjar (assembly of the hamlet) elected its representative to the Pemaksan.

Name: Dadia
Description: A kinship group of the noble houses. The leadership of the dadia (punggawas) passed from the father to the eldest son, which meant that younger sons frequently broke away from their paternal dadia and formed their own dadia, competing for control of land and resources, which led to political intrigues and schisms. A weak network of internal alliances held the dadia together, but it was made ineffective by constant infighting.
Institutional links: Though villages were crosscut by tax obligations to different lords or perbekel, they generally fell under the control of a particular dadia. The weakness of this institution allowed for villages to exercise independence in governing themselves.

Name: Perbekel
Description:
Lord. Each land-owning male owed taxes and specific obligations to a lord or perbekel. Perbekels had a large number of subjects ranging from different villages, but very little actual power to enforce or collect taxes. Thus, in practise, the only obligations each land-owner had to his perbekel were services for rituals and battles. 

Geertz argues that the feudal and perbekel system were fundamentally different despite having the same lord-subject relationship since Bali did not have fiefdoms within which the perbekel exercised control. In addition to being geographically dispersed, the perbekel had very little real authority and was merely a figurative head or 'stagehand' in the theatre state.

Name: War-chief
Description:
'- "A war-party, for better management, had a war-chief, who was the one considered by his companions best qualified to act as a leader." (Teit, p. 289)
- "The chief rarely decided a question without asking the opinion of his fellow-warriors." (p. 289)

- "Under these conditions the title "chief" could not be hereditary; but the fact that a man was the son of a chief gained him a certain amount of popularity." (p. 289)
- "If, however, he failed to possess or attain the necessary qualifications, he was not called "chief", nor would he be considered in any way different from the mass of the people." (p. 289)
- "There were no female chiefs" (p. 289)
- "No particular costumes or ornaments were worn by the chief." (p. 289)

- "If a war-council decided for war, a war-chief was elected, who sent an active young man through the country to invite the warriors to join the party" (p. 290)
- "They generally accompanied the herald upon his return to the meeting-place or to the home of the war-chief who had sent him." (p. 290)
- "It was considered a mark of distinction for a young man to be chosen for this purpose." (p. 290)

Name: Hunting "chief"
Description:
'- "In hunting-parties, the most efficient man took the lead and directed the others, at their request, but subject to their approval." (Teit, p. 289)

- "Under these conditions the title "chief" could not be hereditary; but the fact that a man was the son of a chief gained him a certain amount of popularity." (p. 289)
- "If, however, he failed to possess or attain the necessary qualifications, he was not called "chief", nor would he be considered in any way different from the mass of the people." (p. 289)
- "There were no female chiefs" (p. 289)
- "No particular costumes or ornaments were worn by the chief." (p. 289)

Name: "Chief" of the ceremonies and dances
Description:
'- "In religious ceremonies, a capable man who was looked upon as taking the most prominent part was called the "chief" of the ceremonies and dances." (Teit, p. 289)

- "Under these conditions the title "chief" could not be hereditary; but the fact that a man was the son of a chief gained him a certain amount of popularity." (p. 289)
- "If, however, he failed to possess or attain the necessary qualifications, he was not called "chief", nor would he be considered in any way different from the mass of the people." (p. 289)
- "There were no female chiefs" (p. 289)
- "No particular costumes or ornaments were worn by the chief." (p. 289)

Name: Orators
Description:
'- "Orators possessed great influence and power, often swaying the mass of the people as they chose." (Teit, p. 289)
- "Most of these are said to have favored peace and harmony." (p. 289)
- "When at the same time wise and wealthy, they exerted a very great influence over the people, who willingly obeyed them."(p. 289)
- "Some of them were looked upon as the chief men of certain large districts, the people negotiating through them with strangers; yet they seldom or never acted in matters of public interest without obtaining the consent of all their people." (p. 289)

Name: Informal Councils
Description:
'- "It has been mentioned before that the influential men always consulted with the men of the tribe, but there were no formal councils." (Teit, p. 289)
- "Whenever a man had an undertaking in view that concerned the band, he invited the men of the village to discuss it." (Teit, p. 289)
- "At these councils such subjects as the organising of war-expeditions, marriages, or other matters of public interest, were discussed, each man having a voice in the matter." (Teit, p. 289)
- "Generally the advice of the oldest or the most experienced was taken." (Teit, p.289)
- "If the advice or the help of some leading man noted for his wisdom, who lived at some distance, were desired, a messenger was sent to him." (Teit, p. 289)
- "The man who called the meeting, and his immediate friends, were expected to furnish food to the people assembled." (Teit, p. 289)

- "If a war-council decided for war, a war-chief was elected, who sent an active young man through the country to invite the warriors to join the party" (Teit, p. 290)
- "Women had no voice in these councils, nor in any other matters of importance." (Teit, p. 290)

Name: Babylonian king
Description:
Ruler at the top of the hierarchy. 

Hereditary and divine but not very autocratic because he was delegating a lot of power.

All Mesopotamian kings styled themselves as chosen by gods or in many cases as divine beings.

Name: Karum
Description:
Port authority with economic, administrative, and legal functions related to all matters concerning log-distance trade,

Headed by the overseer of merchants, and heads of important merchant families.
Institutional links: Working together with the College of Judges and the Overseer of the Merchants

Name: Alum
Description:
City Assembly. 

Represents the city as a political, corporate body. 

Unclear who the members are, but probably notables of various kinds and not necessarily the elders.

Name: Sibutu (Elders)
Description: Probably heads of the most influential and wealthiest families of Sippar. gathered to make judicial, diplomatic, administrative, decisions.

Name: Overseer of the Merchants
Description: Head of the Karum. One of the highest ranking officials of the city, first appears as a witness and as a property owner. It has judicial role. Chief administrator of the city. Responsible for the collection of taxes, supervision of the royal granaries

Name: Rabianu or Hazannu
Description: Mayor. Appointed by the king for one-year term.
Institutional links: Head of the elders and superior of the hazannu

Name: Court
Description: Made up of Overseer of merchants, Rabianu, members of the Karum, and college of judges. Probably court overseeing big and important disputes.
Institutional links: Headed by the Overseer of the Merchants

Name: College of Judges
Description: King's judges (coming from both Babylonia and Sippar). They have the local judiciary function, with the possibility to appeal to the king in case there is any dissatisfaction with the verdict rendered.

Name: Sandabakku
Description: Collector of taxes and witness to sale of royal fields. It is a remunerated position, similar to the sukkallu.
Institutional links: Most important of the royal officials.

Name: Sukkallu
Description: Representative of the palace in Sippar
Institutional links: Similar work of the Sandabakku, but less prestigious.

Name: Rakbu
Description: Similar to a messenger. However, specific functions are not clear
Institutional links: Royal official, together with Sandabakku and Sukkallu

Name: Babtu
Description: City wards that constituted Sippar. Small administrative units concerned with local policing and sanitation. Sometimes with functions of judicial body.
Institutional links: It is possible that this administrative unit was headed by the hazannu.

Name: Pukhtunwali
Description: The Code of the Pathans

Name: Jirga
Description: Council of Elders, acting as arbitrator in local feuds. Can impose several forms of punishment. According to Ginsburg, a council of local notables, all equal, who deliberate openly and whose meetings are held in public (though women and children cannot attend)
Institutional links: On equal footing with Malik and Mullah, separation of power 'quasi-constitutional', according to Ginsburg (p. 99)

Name: Malik
Description: Leader (e.g. in a tribe, clan, family...), "primus inter pares"
Institutional links: On equal footing with Jirga and Mullah, separation of power 'quasi-constitutional', according to Ginsburg (p. 99)

Name: Lashkar
Description: Army that can aid the Jirga, disbanded after a task is completed

Name: Mullah
Description: Repository of religious law
Institutional links: On equal footing with Malik and Jirga, separation of power 'quasi-constitutional', according to Ginsburg (p. 99)

Name: King
Description:
Ruler of a city state. 

Monarchical power wanes with time: "Throughout their long history, the Phoenician cities fell under the sway of the Egyptians, Assyrians, Babylonians and later the Persians and Macedonians. Invasion and internal dissension saw the kings' power decline while the councils' base broadened and their power grew. It was during these periods of invasion and upheaval that the councils of elders exerted their authority." Stockwell Before Athens p. 127

Name: Council of Elders
Description:
'local kings consulted on important matters of the state and who could even frustrate a king’s will' (p. 38)

'Acted on their own behalf' (p. 38)
Institutional links: Advised the king but could also act on their own behalf

Name: Assemblies
Description:
Deliberative bodies representing the people. 

Some evidence from the Amarna Letters, from Tunip, Byblos, Arwad and in the towns of Egypt.
Institutional links: Check the king and, from time to time, are sovereign when auhtority of the king wanes

Name: Consuls
Description:
Retributed Members of the Commune, with legislative and economic powers (i.e., able to intervene in transactions on behalf of Pisan church, the city and the contado) 

Heywood, W p. 12 ("The Commune had, in fact, succedeed to all the power of the Visconte, and, from the first decade of the 12th century, we find the Consuls intervening in many transactions which affected the temporalities of the Pisan Church both in the city and in the contado.") | Heywood, W p.241 ("Their salaries were derisory, scarcely indemnifying them for expenses of their office")
Institutional links: The consuls participate in both the Commune Consilium and the Colloquium Civitatis

Name: Commune Consilium of Sapientes or Boni Homines
Description:
Aristocracy of merchants and armatori, participating in the formation of the law, similar to a Senate.

Heywood, W p. 7 ("Thereafter, the Commune was established on a solid legal basis by two, or perhaps three, Imperial diplomas, but the earliest of these was not granted until the second quarter of the 12th century, when the Pisans had already been ruled by their own Consuls for more than forty years") | Heywood, W p. 10 ("There was a Commune Consilium of Sapientes or Boni homines, a species of Senate") | Heywood, W p. 12 ("The Commune had, in fact, succeeded to all the power of the Visconte, and, from the first decade of the 12th century, we find the Consuls intervening in many transactions which affected the temporalities of the Pisan Church both in the city and in the contado.") | Heywood, W p. 13 ("From the nature of the case, the Territorial jurisdiction of the nascent Commune had been purely voluntary, representing as it were the sum of all the fragments of authority which the associated families separately enjoyed and exercised. In process of time, however, as the associative nucleus acquired greater cohesion and stability, a vigorous collective life destroyed the personality of the individual associates, and, little by little, those jurisdictional rights which its members had previously exercised over their own allodial and feudal estates were transferred to the body politic. Thus, almost from the first, the new-born Commune passed considerable territorial jurisdiction, and this it naturally sought to consolidate and enlarge") | Heywood, W p. 235 ("The Commune was in its inception simply a private association; and a private association it long remained. The armatori and merchant adventurers who formed its constituent parts were rather an aristocracy than an oligarchy; and they were able to maintain and extend their authority because they were, in fact, not merely the best but also the only possible interpreters of the aspirations and ambitions of their fellow-citizens") | Heywood, W p.238 ("All the organs of the Commune, whether administrative or judicial, and, indeed, we may almost say the whole population, participated in the formation of the law. The daily routine of communal business enabled the individual citizen to perceive where and how the existing statutes were defective")

Name: Colloquium Civitatis
Description:
Citizen Assembly, largely consultative

Hewyood, W p. 10 ("There was (…) a Colloquim Civitatis or General Assembly of all the citizens, afterwards to develop into the Parlamentum or Arrengo") | Heywood, W p.238 ("When the sense of the community was in favour of a change, the General Council, or the Emendatori, gave concrete form to the popular desire and embodied it in a new rubric")
Institutional links: Made of citizens and consuls, working in parallel with the Commune

Name: Head Captain
Description:
Head Captain did not have absolute authority, and as such was more of the face of the tribe whose job was to welcome visitors and announce the decisions of the Council. He was elected among Hereditary Captains by the people. 

- "From among these [hereditary captains] the people elect a head captain." (Barrett, p. 339)
- "Not even the head captain has absolute authority, nor has any captain important judicial power, or power to inflict punishment." (Barrett, p. 339)
- "The special duties of the head captain in olden times were to welcome and entertain visitors from other villages, and to meet in council with the other captains concerning matters of general public welfare, and to arrange for and preside over ceremonies." (Barrett, p. 339)

- "The captains of the village discussed with other important men the question of holding a ceremony, just as they discussed other matters relating to the general public good." (Barrett, p. 402) 
- "Having agreed upon the date and other details, the head captain usually walked through the village delivering an oration, as was customary upon occasions of importance, in which he announced to the people the decision of their captains." (Barrett, p. 402) 
- "This oration might, however, be delivered as he stood before the door of his own house or before the door of the dance-house." (Barrett, p. 402)
Institutional links:
People elect Head Captain among Hereditary Captains.
They are also members of the Council.

Name: Hereditary Captains
Description:
Heads of the political blood units that formed the village. They made up the majority of the Council and considering the nature of their origin, they most likely acted as the representatives of their units. 

- "As has been elsewhere pointed out,[2] the social organization of the Pomo is based primarily upon blood relationship, the blood relatives who resided in a definite village grouping themselves into a political unit under the leadership of an hereditary "captain."" (Barrett, p. 339)
- "Usually several of these consanguineal units comprise a village, and their captains form its governing body." (Barrett, p. 339) 
- "From among these the people elect a head captain." (Barrett, p. 339)

- "The captains of the village discussed with other important men the question of holding a ceremony, just as they discussed other matters relating to the general public good." (Barrett, p. 402)
- "Having agreed upon the date and other details, the head captain usually walked through the village delivering an oration, as was customary upon occasions of importance, in which he announced to the people the decision of their captains." (Barrett, p. 402)
Institutional links:
Members of the Council.
Amongst them the Head Captain was elected by the people.

Name: Male Honorary Captain
Description:
Male Honorary Captain resembled a rich-person man of its neighbouring tribes (Northern Maidu, Kawaiisu, Tubatulabal, Yuki) in the sense that he was the most popular man in the village. He, however, was not the Hereditary Head of the political blood unit. As such he earned his position on the council through people's trust and respect.

- "What may be termed an honorary captainship was accorded any man who, through his wealth or his prowess as a hunter, made himself very popular by providing large quantities of food and numerous feasts for the people." (Barrett, p. 339)
- "Neither of these honorary offices, however, was hereditary." (Barrett, p. 339)
- "In spite of the ambiguous nature of the office, incumbents were accorded great respect at ceremonies and other public functions."(Barrett, p. 339)
- "The captains of the village discussed with other important men the question of holding a ceremony, just as they discussed other matters relating to the general public good." (Barrett, p. 402)

Name: Female Honorary Captain
Description:
Female Honorary Captain was a female counterpart of the male Honorary Captain and the female version of the 'rich-person man' that was present in the neighbouring tribes (such as Northern Maidu, Kawaiisu, Tubatulabal, Yuki). The most popular woman in the village was awarded this title and hence was allowed to contribute to decision making.

- "A similar honorary office, that of female captain, da´ xalik (E), was based upon a woman's popularity, which depended in turn on her good-heartedness and her fame as a cook." (Barrett, p. 339)
- "Neither of these honorary offices, however, was hereditary." (Barrett, p. 339)
- "In spite of the ambiguous nature of the office, incumbents were accorded great respect at ceremonies and other public functions." (Barrett, p. 339)
- "The captains of the village discussed with other important men the question of holding a ceremony, just as they discussed other matters relating to the general public good." (Barrett, p. 402)

Name: Ceremonial Officials
Description:
There were also other Officials who did not partake in government affairs but were important Ceremonial Officials. See their descriptions below:

- "The other officials had duties almost, if not quite, exclusively connected with ceremonies and had nothing directly to do with governmental affairs." (Barrett, p. 339)
- "We may recognize the fire-tenders, the head singers, the chorus singers, the drummers, and the masters of ceremonies." (Barrett, p. 339)
- "Such offices were considered very honorable and were, as a rule, hereditary." (Barrett, p. 339) 
- "This was particularly true of the offices of fire-tender, head singer, and drummer, in which the succession followed precisely the same rules as did the chieftainship." (Barrett, p. 339)

---Fire-tenders---
- "The fire-tenders, called me´dze (N) and la´imoc (E), were officials of very great importance." (Barrett, p. 339)
- "Connected with each of the large, semi-subterranean "dance-houses"[3] there were two fire-tenders, who saw to all matters concerning the fire and the preparation of the dance-house except actually procuring the firewood." (Barrett, p. 339)
- "All the men participating in the ceremony were supposed to bring wood, which they placed just outside the dance-house." (Barrett, p. 400)
- "One of the fire-tenders then carried it up and dropped it through the smoke-hole, while the other stacked it in ricks in the proper places within the house.2 (Barrett, p. 400)
- "As remuneration for their labor, they received the beads which were thrown at the dancers[4] by the people during the ceremony and which were swept up when the dance-house was cleaned." (Barrett, p. 400)

---Head singer---
- "The head singer, called ke´ kai tca (C) and ke´ūya (E), was a man of great importance in ceremonies, though he was very inconspicuous. It was his duty to plan previously the proper sequence of the dances and songs, and it was also his duty to start all songs and to carry the air." (p. 400)
- "The head singer had to possess a very good voice, and had to make it his business to know the songs for the various ceremonies." (p. 400)
- "Now and then he was at a loss for the proper song for a particular occasion." (p. 400) 
- "He was allowed to consult some other singer, or, upon occasion, he might ask for suggestions from the audience." (p. 400) 
- "Any one who knew a song which fitted the occasion might come to the head singer and sing it for him in an undertone, until he caught it and was ready to lead in the singing." (p. 400) 
- "As a rule he kept time with a split-stick rattle, or a rattle made of cocoons." (p. 400)

---Chorus/Burden-singers---
- "The chorus or burden-singers, called skam (E), gave volume to the music and marked time with their split-stick rattles, hai mitamitaka (N)." (p. 400) 
- "Their usual burden was "he, he, he, he, ..." sung in a heavy monotone." (p. 400)

---Drummers---
- "The drummers, called tsīlo´ gaūk (E), tsīlo´ tca (C), and tsīlo´ matūtsī (E), were always two in number, and as a rule they took turns in playing the large wooden drum which was set in the ground at the rear of the dance-house, and which was beaten by the stamping of the feet." (p. 400) 
- "The office of drummer was considered one of the most important, and second only to that of fire-tender." (p. 400)

Master of ceremonies
- "The master of ceremonies, called xabē´ dima (E), xabē´gaūk (E), and he´līma (C), started and stopped all songs and dances by certain signals." (p. 400) 
- "The participants in the dance usually maintained certain positions, but the master of ceremonies ran about from place to place supervising the activities and giving directions as required." (p. 400) 
- "His presence was absolutely necessary at all ceremonies, and without him a dance could not proceed." (p. 401) 
- "He acted under the general direction of the head captain, but that official himself never served as master of ceremonies." (p. 401) 
- "Very rarely did the same individual serve as master of ceremonies and head singer." (p. 401) 
- "While as a rule the drummers and the singers wore no special dress for ceremonial occasions, the masters of ceremonies were almost always painted and dressed according to different requirements for each ceremony (see below)." (p. 401) 
- "They were usually among the dancers who impersonated supernatural beings." (p. 401)
Institutional links: Master of ceremonies acted under the general direction of the Head Captain

Name: Council
Description:
Consisted of the Head Captain, Hereditary Captains and Honorary Captains. Hereditary Captains represented their political blood units. Honorary Captains were there because of their popularity. And the Head Captain was an elected body that announced the decisions made by the Council. 
Council was concerned with general public welfare as well as ceremonies.
These Captains, however, also discussed these matters with other important men.


- "The special duties of the head captain in olden times were to welcome and entertain visitors from other villages, and to meet in council with the other captains concerning matters of general public welfare, and to arrange for and preside over ceremonies." (Barrett, p. 339)
- "The captains of the village discussed with other important men the question of holding a ceremony, just as they discussed other matters relating to the general public good." (Barrett, p. 402)
Institutional links:
Consisted of captains (Head Captain, Hereditary Captains and Honorary Captains).
Consulted with other important men.

Name: Communal Assembly (skhod)
Description:
An assembly open to every member of the commune, who participated in arriving at most decisions. It was also a place where officials were elected, who were responsible for certain matters. It was run mostly by peasant elders, and the right to vote was reserved by male heads of households (but when unable to attend they could give their votes to proxies, who could be women). 

-	"Members of each settlement attended volost’ assembly (skhod), which elected communal officials, including an elder and tax collector." (Moon, p. 201)
-       "Run mostly by peasant elders" (Moon, p. 199)
-	"The commune meetings seem to have been informal gatherings at which any villager could speak, but the right to vote was limited to the male heads of households." (Blum, p. 524)
-	"If a head of a household could not attend he could give his vote to a proxy, who could be a woman." (Blum, p. 524)
-	"Usually a simple majority was enough to carry a motion, but on important questions a majority of two thirds was considered necessary." (Blum, p. 524)
-	"The entire commune participated in arriving at most decisions." (Blum, p. 524)

- "Communes directed the village economy, especially the three-field system of crop rotation." (Moon, p. 199)
- "Communes played a vital role in supervising the cultivation and use of their land." (Blum, p. 222)
- "Communes directed the clearance of land from forest or steppe in the long-fallow systems used in the earlier times, and later, in some outlying regions." (Blum, p. 222)
- "Communal tenure and regulation did not mean collective farming: households cultivated their strips of arable land individually." (Blum, p. 222)
- "Nevertheless, every household had to sow and harvest the same crops in each field at the same time." (Blum, p. 222)
- "Since the fields were split into many strips worked by different households, communal tillage had to be practiced." (Blum, p. 525)
- "That is, everyone had to perform the same operations in the fields at the same time." (Blum, p. 525)
- "The mir decided what work was to be done in a field and when to do it." (Blum, p. 525)
- "It had its own treasury, built up by levies on its members or by sale of communally produced goods, and used the money to care for its indigent, sick and aged members, and to rent and even buy land so that it would have more to parcel out." (Blum, p. 525)
- "It usually determined the order in which its young men went into the army as recruits." (Blum, p. 525)

- "Many communes made some provision for the welfare of their members." (Moon, p. 225)
- "Communes sometimes temporarily suspended or waived the obligations of weaker households, or lent them money." (Moon, p. 225)
- "Communes organised assistance (pomoch’) for households that had fallen on hard times by arranging for some villagers to help out with arduous tasks, or to cultivate land for families that lacked the labourers to do it for themselves." (Moon, p. 225)
- "Households that received assistance rewarded their helpers with food and drink, especially vodka." (Moon, p. 226)
- "Pomoch’ was a kind of mutual insurance policy." (Moon, p. 226)
- "The households’ misfortune was short term and, in time, they would once again be economically viable and capable of making their contribution to the commune’s obligations." (Moon, p. 226)
- "Communes were not prepared to provide a permanent “safety net” for all poor families." (Moon, p. 226)
- "They did not want to use valuable resources supporting households whose hardships seemed long term since they would become “free riders”." (Moon, p. 226)
Institutional links: Elected communal officials including an elder and tax collector

Name: Tax collector
Description:
Collected tax for the Duke

-	"Members of each settlement attended volost’ assembly (skhod), which elected communal officials, including an elder and tax collector." (Moon, p. 201)
-	"The commune’s own assessors had to apportion these royal taxes and obligations equitably among its members, gather the levies, and turn them over to the duke's officials." (p. 96)
Institutional links:

Name: Clerk
Description:
Member of the Christian Orthodox church responsible for keeping records.

-	"The clerk of the mir enjoyed much power and prestige, for often he was the only person in the commune who could read and write. "(Blum, p. 523)
-	"Unfortunately, his learning was usually small and his palm easily crossed." (Blum, p. 523)
-	"As a result, in many communes the account books were in a state of confusion." (Blum, p. 523)
- "The clergy was an hereditary caste." (Blum, p. 55)
- "Sons were presumably trained to follow their fathers into the ministry; the boy who had not learned his letters was unable to enter the calling for which he was destined." (Blum, p. 55)
Institutional links: There was one in each commune. Member of Church.

Name: Commune Officials
Description:
Elected by the commune members through the Communal Assembly (skhod). Were responsible for the redistribution of holdings, arrangements of marriages, maintenance of public order and security within the commune's boundaries and provisions of guardians for orphans and the feeble-minded.

-	"Members of each settlement attended volost’ assembly (skhod), which elected communal officials, including an elder and tax collector." (Moon, p. 201)
-	"Each commune was semi-autonomous, and was run by officers chosen by the commune members from among their fellows." (Blum, p. 96)
-	"The volost managed all those parts of its territory that were not held by individual peasants, such as forests, common pasture, streams, and fisheries." (Blum, p. 96)
-	"It supervised the establishment of new homesteads within its boundaries, the distribution of unoccupied arable, and the resettling of vacated holdings." (Blum, p. 96)
-	"Newcomers were welcomed, sometimes being given several years of freedom from paying their share of the communal obligations." (Blum, p. 96)
-	"Volost officials were also responsible for the maintenance of public order and security within the commune’s boundaries." (Blum, p. 96)
-      "Certain matters such as the redistribution of holdings, arrangements of marriages, and provisions of guardians for orphans and the feeble-minded, were left to the discretion of the officials elected by the commune." (Blum, p. 524)
-      "Its officials assisted the proprietor in punishing minor infractions, and often he imposed severe penalties such as exile at their suggestion." (Blum, p. 525)

Name: Duke
Description:
The ruler of the region, where communes were located to whom tax had to be paid in order to self-govern.

-	"But the ruler of each princedom considered the black land, like all real property in his realm, part of his patrimony." (Blum, p. 93)
-	"The black people themselves accepted it by paying him a regular quitrent." (Blum, p. 93)
-	"They acted as if land belonged to them, buying and selling holdings to one another or passing them on to their heirs." (Blum, p. 93)
-	"Although the land held by the peasant actually belonged to a private proprietor, or to the prince if it was black land, the peasant had virtually all the rights of ownership over his holding, so long as he worked it, and so long as he paid the obligations demanded by its proprietor. " (Blum, p. 97)
-	"He could rent or sell the use of all or part of it to anyone he chose, provided that the new occupant was a person capable of working the land and meeting the obligations attached to its possession, he could mortgage it, and he could dispose of it as he wished in his testament." (Blum, p. 97)
-	"He could stay on it as long as he wanted, and he was free to leave it at his own discretion (although the time of his departure began to be regulated in the latter 15th century)." (Blum, p. 97)
-	"The extensive rights of the Russian peasants over their holdings were analogous to those enjoyed by peasants in other lands of Eastern and Central Europe, who lived under the provisions of the so-called “German Law”." (Blum, p. 97)

-	"The prince levied his imposts upon the commune as a unit, and not upon the persons or lands or incomes of its individual members." (Blum, p. 96)

Liza's Note: sources in English refer to this position both as 'Duke' and 'Prince', but in my opinion 'Duke' is the closest translation.

First, there was always significant formal weight given to Siena’s merchant guild in selecting both the members of the Nine and the members of the Council of the Bell. Second, there were specific restrictions on the types of individuals who could serve on the Nine.

Name: Congress of confederate representatives
Description:
Assembly of delegates representing the cantons, also known as confederal diet (Tagsatzung). Decides upon all maters, including currently, defense and foreign treaties (Lau, p. 188ff)

Delegates from the urban cantons were elected in town councils, delegates from rural cantons were elected by assemblies open to all free men (with some exceptions). They all have a fixed term in office. they all belong to the local elites

Decision to hold a meeting of the diet could come upon request from any cantons

Majority voting used for administrative matters, unanimity for everything else.

Debate follows a very formal procedure " The very formalised procedure (Umfrage) followed a fixed order. The first allowed to speak was always the mayor of Zurich. Those who were the
first in line (like Zurich, Berne, Schwyz and Lucerne) were the most influential. The others usually agreed with one of these leading opinion makers. The procedure went on until a unanimous vote was reached or the cantons agreed to drop the matter." p. 189

Name: Assemblies of the rural cantons
CGI: Assembly (local),Frequent and/or regular meetings,Tribunal/Court ,Election,Temporary position of power/Term Limits,Life appointment
Description:
Local assembly of free peasants in a canton The right to participate in the decision-making process was not granted to all inhabitants of the rural cantons. Women and foreigners were excluded from the cantonal assemblies.

"In Schwyz, Uri, Unterwalden, Appenzell and Glarus, the assemblies of the citizens acted as the supreme powers. In Schwyz, these assemblies were held once a year on the last Sunday in May. When questions of crucial importance were left unresolved at this
meeting, a second one was summoned two or three weeks later. The assembly acted as a high court of justice, decided on new laws and charters, ratified treaties and elected the main office-holders of the canton. The head of the administration (Landamann), his deputy (Statthalter) and the treasurer (Sa¨ckelmeister) served for two years. Other officers and members of the court were appointed by the assembly for life. The members the council served as custodians of the assembly’s rights between sessions and were elected by local meetings held by each of the six quarters. They were responsible for their acts to the assembly and all acknowledged the assembly as the
supreme power of the canton. Although office-holders usually proposed the agenda, any member of the assembly had the right to put forward a motion. Freedom of speech was guaranteed. Once a resolution had been passed, every citizen was expected to obey
it. The assembly’s competence was unlimited." Lau p. 191.

Name: Officeholders of the rural cantons
Description:
The head of the administration (Landamann), his deputy (Statthalter) and the treasurer (Sa¨ckelmeister) served for two years. Other officers and members of the court were appointed by the assembly for life. 

Although office-holders usually proposed the agenda, any member of the assembly had the right to put forward a motion.
